item.content:encoded:
Dear Marv, Mareon, Murrell and Mya,

I have something to tell you. Something I want to talk about.Â

Itâ€™s something Iâ€™ve mostly kept to myself up to now, and you might not fully understand it right at this moment, but I need for you to hear it.

Itâ€™s tough to talk about even all these months later, but after your little brother Marlo passed away in Decemberâ€¦.

Daddy was ready to call it quits.

Not just football, either. Iâ€™m talking just get away from â€¦ everything.

Leave the country. Move to Spain. Hunker down. Just us and Mommy. That sort of thing. Never talk to anyone ever again, never have to face anyone or discuss anything, just shield us all from the entire outside world. You know what I mean?

We were all just struggling so much.

Mom and me was one thing, but hearing Mya ask, â€œWhen is Marlo coming back down from heaven?â€ Seeing that teddy bear that you guys called by his name? It was beyond heartbreaking.

We always told you guys it was O.K. to cry and to let your feelings out.

But sometimes thatâ€™s not so easy. Even for Dad.

Me and Mommy tried our best to stay strong in front of you guys, and to make sure you understood that we were going to get through this no matter what. We knew youâ€™d be watching us â€” looking to us for how we were handling such an unimaginable tragedy. So we did our best. But the reality is.â€¦

I was really hurting.

Early on Iâ€™d try to act â€œnormalâ€ all day and not show any hurt, and then Iâ€™d just lie down in bed at night and itâ€™d all come out at once. So, yeah, those first few days, it all just felt like too much.

But thatâ€™s not what I wanted to tell you.

I mention all that stuff because I need you to understand the backdrop for what I do want to talk about. And that isâ€¦.

What happened next.

A few days after our little angel left us, as sad as we all were â€¦ something truly amazing happened. Something inspiring.

And thatâ€™s actually what I want to tell you about.

All of sudden, folks just kept showing up at our front door. And, at first, I gotta be honest ... I didnâ€™t want to answer. But the doorbell just kept ringing.

Matthew and Kelly Stafford.

Danny Amendola.

Kenny Golladay.

Coach Patricia. Coach Prince. Other members of the organization.Â

All showing us love. Giving us support. Letting us know that they were there for us.

I mean, you guys ... it was so moving what they did for our family.

Iâ€™m getting choked up right now just sitting here writing about it. But back then? In that moment? Iâ€™m not lying when I say that their visits, that supportâ€¦.

It changed something inside of me.

I went from wanting to be closed off and isolated from pretty much everyone to realizing beyond a shadow of a doubt that our family needed all the love and support we could get.

So after those first few visits, our door was wide open. You guys remember it. Everyone in the family flew up to Michigan. Your grandparents, aunts and uncles on both sides. Auntie Leslie even flew in from China.

Everyone rallied around us.

And as tough as those first few days were, I always want you guys to remember how our family and friends came together to lift us up and help us all get through the most difficult experience of our lives.

Local businesses and restaurants sent over food and care packages. Police and firefighters stopped by to lend their support. Friends, sports fans, and just regular folks from all around the world sent us their well-wishes and shared their stories of loss with us to make sure we knew we werenâ€™t alone.Â

It was powerful. And it goes to show something I want you guys to always rememberâ€¦.Â

It really does take a community sometimes. Sometimes you canâ€™t do things on your own.

People need people.

It really does take a community sometimes. Sometimes you canâ€™t do things on your own. People need people.

The other big point to remember â€” and this is maybe the most important thing of all in terms of your lives going forward â€” is that the good people in this world outnumber the bad by a wide margin. Those who are kindhearted and eager to lend a hand â€¦ those folks are everywhere.

Please never doubt that for a second.Â

I know itâ€™s sometimes easy to get down about the negativity and hatred and pessimism that we see online or on the news, but those people, that mindset? When push comes to shove â€¦ it has no chance against the good people of the world.

When something like what happened to us takes place, you learn that real quick.

But the important thing is that you never forget it.

That you never stop letting it inspire you to show that same love and compassion throughout your own lives. I can tell you for certain that the kindness and support that our family received made a lasting impact on Mommy and me.

Your mom is in the process of starting up a foundation that will help other families who have gone through what we all experienced over the past year â€” a place for sharing stories, and where families can lend support to one another.

And the outpouring of support we experienced over this past year definitely inspired us to want to do even more once the pandemic hit. Daddy looked at himself in the mirror and asked, Am I doing enough to help right now? Mommy did the same. And we both agreed that we needed to do all that we could to support first responders and everyone else putting their own health and well-being on the line for the rest of us. We wanted to do our part to let those folks know that they were not alone, and that we all had their backs, and to help them feel the same power of community that had lifted us up over the past year.

Iâ€™m so proud that you guys were with us for every step of that journey, and the joy and happiness that you each experienced from helping others is something that will be in my heart forever.

It was inspiring for me.

At the same time, while the struggles and suffering of the coronavirus pandemic were going down, we all couldnâ€™t help but look for silver linings wherever we could find them. And as heartbreaking as the pandemic has been on so many levels, I have to say that I am grateful that it has allowed our family to be together for an extended period of time â€” and at a moment when I truly believe that we needed that more than ever.

After your brotherâ€™s passing, we absolutely needed to be together like that, we really, really did. And for your mom and me, being able to spend so much time with you guys was a blessing.

Believe me when I tell you, every moment together this year has been cherished.

To the fullest.

Often people tend to think that the parents do everything for their kids, and teach all the lessons and set the standard, but in so many ways, it was actually your resilience and strength and positivity that helped us get through this year.Â

And at the end of the day we all made it through together.

I donâ€™t want to go on too long â€” I know for a fact that a few of you have Zoom homework assignments to get to! â€” but before I get out of here, there are just two last things I want to make sure you understand.

First, please know that during the past year you guys have brought an immense amount of joy into Mommy and Daddyâ€™s lives. Even in the hardest of times, you allowed us to see and experience what real, pure love looks like.

Sometimes us grown-ups make life so complicated, and get caught up in our jobs, or all the other things that we need to take care of from day to day. But you guys, you brought Mom and me back to our childhoods this year. Just watching you run around and jump and laugh, and then doing all those things right alongside you guys â€¦ it really was the best.

Everything became so simple and genuine and pure. You guys made it all about love, and appreciating our time together, and that really put everything in perspective for us. I canâ€™t tell you how much that meant to me and Mommy.

It was like we were both 12 again â€” playing kickball in the house, trying to remember the rules of handball, having epic Barbie doll playdates, doing double Dutch (DOUBLE DUTCH!!!) together. All of a sudden, we were back in the â€™90s.

And you guys had us laughing and smiling again.

Heck, Marv even taught me how to make TikToks!

At one point I remember pulling your mom aside and whispering, â€œAre these our kids or our siblings?â€

Because we were all having so much fun together.

You guys, you brought Mom and me back to our childhoods this year.

Of course, weâ€™ll never ever forget Marlo. Weâ€™ll always remember the wonderful times we had together with him. And I know heâ€™s been smiling down on us from heaven while weâ€™ve been doing all that stuff together. I know heâ€™s proud of you guys, and he surely knows how much of a difference you made in helping your parents cope this year.

So on behalf of both Mom and I, and your baby brother Marlo, I just want to sayâ€¦.

Thank you.

And last, but certainly not least, I just want to say that Mommy and me are so excited for you guys to meet the newest member of our family.

After Marlo was born, your mom and I had decided that there werenâ€™t going to be any additional brothers or sisters joining our family. But after his passing ... you guys let it be known that you had other ideas.Â Â

And, I mean â€¦ how could we ignore that?

It was probably the fastest and easiest change of plans in the history of the world.

And now, when your baby sister arrives in February, you guys can know that she is here because of Marlo, and because of what he meant to you guys. What he still means to all of us.

Your baby sister will be another of about a million reminders of how special Marlo was.

And, you know what elseâ€¦? She is going to be joining one heck of a family!

With all my love,

Daddy

item.title: Not an Underdog Story
item.author: Kyle Lowry
item.description:
"Do I think weâ€™re getting enough respect as the defending champs? Hell no. But also, do I care? Nah, not really.
Donâ€™t matter. We still the champs."
item.content:encoded:
I get asked all the time now to explain the feeling.Â

Whatâ€™s it feel like to win your first championship?

It seems like a simple question to answer. After all, Iâ€™d been working toward that first championship in one way or another my whole life. But, still, Iâ€™m just not quite sure I can capture the feeling of it in just a few words.

After you put so much time and passion into this game, thereâ€™s a lot of emotion that gets attached to theÂ ideaÂ of being a champion. Having that validation. And the closer you get to realizing that goal without getting there â€” withoutÂ actuallyÂ reaching that pinnacle â€” the more it hurts.Â

I never won a championship in high school. We lost in the Catholic League championship game my junior and senior years. Lost to UNC in the tournament as a freshman at â€™Nova,Â then to Florida when I was a sophomore. Both those teams would go on to win the whole tournament.

Then I got to the league and, well, I guess the best way to put it is that if you told someone 10 years ago that Iâ€™d one day be an NBA champion as a member of theÂ Toronto Raptors, they probably wouldnâ€™t have known which part was more ridiculous.

But maybe the reason I canâ€™t explain how winning a championship actually feels is because Iâ€™m still processing it all, Iâ€™m stillÂ inÂ it.Â

And hereâ€™s the thing, even though the specific moment â€” how it felt, what it meant â€” is hard to really put into words, what I do know is that itâ€™s mine. It belongs to me, my family, my teammates, my coaches and to all of Toronto. And, man, thatâ€™s all that matters.Â

And that brings me to the next thing people will ask about sometimes: Do I think weâ€™re getting enough respect as the defending champs?Â

HellÂ no.Â

But also, do I care?

Nah, not really.Â

Do I think weâ€™re getting enough respect as the defending champs? Hell no.

This isnâ€™t new. Toronto will never get the respect we deserve because weâ€™re the only Canadian franchise in the league. Itâ€™s been like that since Iâ€™ve been here.Â

It was a long, hard road for me, getting to the championship â€” and it was a long, hard road for the team and the organization. But we got there.

They can talk their talk, and think whatever they want. But the fact remains the same: We got a ring ceremony, and all they got is a tired take.Â

Donâ€™t matter. We still the champs.Â

People throw it out there a lot, but Iâ€™ve never really liked being described as an underdog.

It kind of makes it sound like I got where I am just because Iâ€™m lucky.Â

Make no mistake â€” thereâ€™s definitely some luck involved. But thatâ€™s true of every single guy in the league â€” really every person who has achieved a dream they had as a kid. But when it comes to sticking in the league, competing, growing as a player to get where I am today â€“ none of that was luck. Thatâ€™s been a process.

Want to hear a real underdog story? A kid from one of the most dangerous places in America getting a four-year scholarship to Villanova.Â

Thatâ€™s not just an underdog story, thatâ€™s a borderline miracle where Iâ€™m from.

No matter how big the stage or the moment, basketball is a fantasy. No matter what the result or how I play, thereâ€™s no actualÂ pressure when it comes to basketball.

Real life is pressure.

Pressure is walking through the snow for miles just grinding it out because itâ€™s the only way you can get around. Pressure is waiting around for your cousin who has the WIC program so you can grab free milk, and maybe some Juicy Juices if youâ€™re lucky. Pressure is your mom working two jobs while also trying to put in enough time as a parent so her child isnâ€™t one of the many who end up dead or in jail.Â

Thatâ€™s real life.Â

But basketball? Thatâ€™s always been a sanctuary. No matter how intense the game is.Â Â

My upbringing molded my game. Playing streetball at Connie Mack on 22nd and Lehigh in North Philly was where I got my education. My brother, Lonnie, is five years older than me, but heâ€™d always make sure I was on his team. When youâ€™re the youngest guy on the court and every other player is bigger and stronger than you, the job description is simple: Hustle. Take charges, dive for balls, set picks and doÂ notÂ shootÂ (but always make it when you do).

But, most of all, be tough. Thatâ€™s not optional. Fortunately, the toughness thing was always the easiest part for me. That part I didnâ€™t need to put the work in on or refine. It was inherited â€” from my grandma.Â

She passed earlier this year, and that was really tough because she was my person, you know? Like we just understood each other because we were very similar. She had this hard edge about her but we all knew how much she cared about everyone. Everything she did was for others.Â

Still, she was not somebody to be messed with.

Iâ€™ll never forget when I was in elementary school and got in a fight. As soon as it got broken up and I got sent to the principalâ€™s office, I was only thinking about one thing: Oh damn, my grandma is going to beat my ass!

Basketball? Thatâ€™s always been a sanctuary. No matter how intense the game is.

I swear on everything I was sitting in that principalâ€™s office, and she was like, â€œKyle, this is serious. Youâ€™re going to be suspended.â€ And my only response was to plead with her, â€œFine,Â do whatever, please just donâ€™t tell my grandma! Please,Â pleaseÂ donâ€™t call my grandma!â€

My walk home from school that day was like a funeral march. My mom has always been much more relaxed, but grandma was the disciplinarian. And I knew I was in for it this time.Â

As soon as I got home, she was there, just waiting. I felt this chill. And Iâ€™ll never forget what she said to me.

â€œWell, did you win?â€

I didnâ€™t know if it was a trick or what. I just nodded.

â€œUh-huh.â€

Then she gave the tiniest grin and just said,Â â€œAlright then.â€Â

And that was that. Iâ€™d gotten much, much worse for accidentally spilling milk before, but she let this one slide.Â

For a long time I didnâ€™t understand why. But once I became a dad, it made a little more sense. It was her way of teaching me about toughness. Was it a perfect way? Will you find in parenting books? Nah, you probably wonâ€™t.Â But everyone has their own different ways of doing things and showing you their love and how to become a better person.Â

Donâ€™t fight.Â

But if youâ€™re going to fight? Win.Â

Iâ€™m proud of where Iâ€™m from, and of where Iâ€™ve made it to.Â But one thing about growing up in a rough environment is that itâ€™s difficult to learn how to trust people.

Trust is a luxury that a lot of people in desperate situations canâ€™t afford. And as a result itâ€™s easy to become isolated when you feel like you arenâ€™t in a good situation. When I left home, and especially when I got to the league, it was hard for me to develop that level of trust you need to be part of a winning organization.

Part of the reason for that is because I learned about the business side of basketball pretty quickly after being drafted by Memphis. I arrived there as a rookie believingÂ thatÂ I was their point guard of the future, then exactly a year later I was at the draft party when the team selected Mike Conley.

Honestly, it was a great pick. Mikeâ€™s one of the best in the league to this day. But of course at the time, I wasnâ€™t thinking that. I didnâ€™t see it coming at all. I had no idea they would select a point guard. As soon as that pick was made, the reality struck me that there truly are no guarantees in the NBA.Â

When I got traded to Houston, I was ready to prove to everyone what I could do. I worked harder than I ever have to get minutes and respect. I was coming off the best season of my career when Kevin McHale was hired as coach. From the very start of that year, I had the wrong mentality. I thought that because I was coming off a good year, I was the man. I deserved better treatment. And coach gave me the exact opposite. He was hard on me. Really hard on me. At the time, I wasnâ€™t able to see what he was trying to do. I didnâ€™t get that he saw that I was a good, tough player, but still had more room to grow if I was pushed.Â

Iâ€™m proud of where Iâ€™m from, and of where Iâ€™ve made it to. But one thing about growing up in a rough environment is that itâ€™s difficult to learn how to trust people.

I didnâ€™t know the answer to, Why is he being so hard on me? was simply, Heâ€™s making you better.

When I ended up getting traded to Toronto, it almost felt like I was getting sent into exile. I didnâ€™t know anything about Toronto. At the time I didnâ€™t care to know. I just thought this was going to be a pit stop until an opportunity somewhere else.

But then, not long after I arrived, I found that I had it all wrong. This place wasnâ€™t just a pit stop. This was an amazing city and had a fanbase that people were sleeping on. All they really needed to get it going was a winner.

Those early days in Toronto we knew there was no guarantees that they would keep the team together. At that point a lot of us had been cast off by other organizations. We all got on the same page pretty quickly. We played for each other. And I met DeMar, who became one of my best friends and an All-Star, and we started building something. We had that trust.

To make it to the Finals and hoist that trophy, there were a lot more sacrifices that had to be made. We lost people who had helped build this whole thing up. We let go of Case, traded DeMar, traded JV â€” moves that, even though you know they are part of the business, cut real deep.

Then we built a roster of players who all get after you. And, yeah, ultimately, we got a little lucky. We had some timely plays and we got a few bounces â€” three or four off the rim just against Philly.

We did what we had to do, when we had to it, in order to get things done.

And now, after all that â€” the work, the fun, the frustration â€” only one thing matters: We the champs.

One thing I know for sure is that just winning a championship wonâ€™t fulfill you. It doesnâ€™t feel like the end of a journey.

Instead it pushes you. Because now it isnâ€™t this dream or idea â€” now you know what it takes, and you know how it feels to get there. And once that happens, all you want is to do everything in your power to feel it again. Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s driving me this year. Thatâ€™s what got me up early to head right back to the gym a week after our parade.

Weâ€™re going to be looking forward to Ring Night. No question about that. But once that banner gets raised to the rafters, we wonâ€™t be looking up at it too long. All the focus will be on getting another one. Because that one isnâ€™t going anywhere. Itâ€™s staying right there.

Only one thing matters: We the champs.

Last month, I brought the Larry Oâ€™Brien trophy back to my house. At one point both of my sons were playing with it. MyÂ youngerÂ son, Kam, was running and jumping around the trophy, putting his fingerprints all over it. And my older son, Karter, was just sort of looking at it in amazement. Like,Â How is this thing here with us right now in this moment?Â

One day, when heâ€™s a bit older, Iâ€™ll tell him how it got here. Itâ€™s a long story. But itâ€™s a great story. And no matter what, one fact will never change.

Toronto Raptors, NBA champions.Â

Kyle Lowry, NBA champion.

Thatâ€™s forever.Â Â

item.title: Letter to My Younger Self
item.author: Ronaldinho
item.description: You are smiling because football is fun. Why would you be serious? Your goal is to spread joy. Creativity over calculation.
item.content:encoded:
Dear eight-year-old Ronaldinho,

Tomorrow, when you come home from playing football, there will be a lot of people in your house. Your uncles, friends of your family and some other people you wonâ€™t recognize will be in the kitchen. At first, youâ€™ll think youâ€™re just late for the party. Everybodyâ€™s there to celebrate the 18th birthday of your brother, Roberto.

Usually when you come home from football, mom is always laughing or joking around.

But this time, sheâ€™ll be crying.

And then you will see Roberto. He will put his arm around you and bring you inside the bathroom so you can be alone. Then he will tell you something you wonâ€™t understand.

â€œThere was an accident. Dad is gone. He died.â€

It wonâ€™t make sense to you. What does that mean? When is he coming back? How could dad be gone?

Dad was the one who told you play creatively on the football pitch, the one who told you to play with a free style â€” to just play with the ball. He believed in you more than anyone. When Roberto started playing professional football for GrÃªmio last year, Dad told everyone, â€œRoberto is good, but watch his younger brother coming up.â€

Dad was a superhero. He loved football so much that even after working at the shipyard during the week, he would work security at GrÃªmioâ€™s stadium on the weekend. How could you never see him again? You wonâ€™t understand what Roberto is telling you.

Youâ€™re not going to feel sadness right away. That will come later. A few years from now, you will accept that Dad is never coming back on earth. But what I want you to understand is that every time you have a ball at your feet, Dad will be with you.

When you have a football at your feet, you are free. You are happy. Itâ€™s almost like you are hearing music. That feeling will make you want to spread joy to others.

You are lucky because you have Roberto. Even though heâ€™s 10 years older and already playing for GrÃªmio, Roberto will be there for you always. He wonâ€™t just be a brother, he will become like a father to you. And more than anything, heâ€™ll be your hero.

Youâ€™ll want to play like him, youâ€™ll want to be like him. Every morning, when you head to GrÃªmio â€” you will play for the youth side, while Roberto plays for the senior team â€” youâ€™ll get to walk into the locker room with your big brother, the football star. And every night, when you go to bed, youâ€™ll think, I get to share a room with my idol.

There are no posters on the walls in the bedroom you share, thereâ€™s only a small TV. It wonâ€™t matter anyway, because you wonâ€™t have time to watch any matches together. When heâ€™s not traveling for matches, Roberto is taking you outside to play more football.

Where you live in Porto Alegre, there are drugs and gangs and that kind of stuff around. Itâ€™s going to be tough, but as long as you are playing football â€” on the street, at the park, with your dog â€” you will feel safe.

Yes, I said your dog, by the way. Heâ€™s a tireless defender.

Youâ€™ll play with Roberto. Youâ€™ll play with other kids and older guys at the park. But eventually everyone will get tired â€” and you will want to keep playing. So make sure you always take your dog, Bombom, out with you. Bombom is a mutt. A real Brazilian dog. And even Brazilian dogs love football. Heâ€™ll be great practice for dribbling and skills â€¦ and maybe the first casualty of the â€œElastico.â€

Years from now, when you are playing in Europe, a few defenders will remind you of Bombom.

Childhood is going to be very different for you. By the time youâ€™re 13, people will have started talking about you. Theyâ€™ll talk about your skills and what youâ€™re able to do with a ball. At this time, football is still just a game to you. But in 1994, when you are 14, the World Cup will show you that football is more than just a simple game.

July 17, 1994, is a day every Brazilian remembers. On that day, youâ€™ll be traveling with the GrÃªmio youth team for a match in Belo Horizonte. The World Cup final is on TV, and itâ€™ll be Brazil against Italy. Yes, thatâ€™s right, the Canarinho will be in a World Cup final for the first time in 24 years. The whole country will seem to stop.

Everywhere in Belo Horizonte, there will be Brazilian flags. There will be no colors except green and yellow that day. Every single spot in the city will have the match turned on and be filled with people.

Youâ€™ll be watching with your teammates. The final whistle will blow with the score tied 0â€“0. The game will go to a penalty shootout.

Italy misses their first PK, and so does Brazil. Then Italy scores. And then â€¦ Romario steps up. His shot curves to the left â€¦ hits the post â€¦ and flies in the goal. The guys on the team are screaming and yelling.

Italy scores and thereâ€™s silence again.

Branco scores for Brazil â€¦ Taffarel makes a save for Brazil â€¦ Dunga scores for Brazil.â€¦

Then, the moment that will not just change your life, but the lives of millions of Brazilians.â€¦

Baggio steps up to the spot for Italy and misses.

Brazil are World Cup champions.

During the crazy celebration, itâ€™s going to become clear to you what you want to do for the rest of your life. Youâ€™re going to finally realize what football means to Brazilians. Youâ€™re going to feel the power of this sport. Most importantly, you will see the happiness that football can bring to regular people.

â€œIâ€™m going to play for Brazil,â€ youâ€™ll tell yourself that day.

Not everyone is going to believe in you, especially with the way you play.

There will be some coaches â€” alright, one in particular â€” who will tell you not to play the way you do. He will think you need to be more serious, that you need to stop dribbling so much. â€œYouâ€™ll never in your life make it as a footballer,â€ heâ€™ll say.

Use those words as motivation. Use them to keep you focused. And then think about the players who did play the game beautifully â€” Dener, Maradona, Ronaldo.

Think about what Dad said, to play free and to just play with the ball. Play with joy. This is something that many coaches will not understand, but when you are on the pitch, you will never calculate. Everything will come naturally. Before you have time to think, your feet have already made a decision.

Creativity will take you further than calculation.

One day, just a few months after you watch Romario lift the â€™94 World Cup, your coach at GrÃªmio is going to pull you into his office after training. Heâ€™ll tell you that youâ€™ve been called up to the Brazilian under-17 national team. When you get to the training camp in TeresÃ³polis, you will see something that you will never forget: When you walk into the cafeteria, youâ€™ll notice the framed photos hanging on the walls â€” PelÃ©, Zico, Bebeto.

Youâ€™ll be walking the same halls as those legends. Youâ€™ll sit at the same cafeteria tables that Romario, Ronaldo and Rivaldo sat in. Youâ€™ll eat the same food they ate. Youâ€™ll sleep in the same dorms they slept in. When you put your head down to sleep, your last thought will be, I wonder which of my heroes slept on this pillow, too.

For the next four years, you will do nothing but play football. You will spend your life on buses and training pitches. In fact, from 1995 to 2003, you will never take a vacation. It will be very intense

But when you turn 18, you will achieve something your father would have been very proud of. You will make your debut for GrÃªmioâ€™s senior team. The only sad part is that Roberto wonâ€™t be there. A knee injury will cut his time at GrÃªmio short and heâ€™ll go to Switzerland to play. You wonâ€™t get to share the pitch with your hero, but youâ€™ve spent so many years watching Roberto that youâ€™ll know what to do and how to act.

On match days, youâ€™ll walk through the car park where your father used to work security on the weekends. Youâ€™ll enter the dressing room where your brother used to take you as a kid. Youâ€™ll pull on the blue and black GrÃªmio shirt. Youâ€™ll think: Life canâ€™t get any better than this. Youâ€™ll think you have finally made it, playing for your hometown club.

But this is not where your story ends.

The next year, you will play your first senior match with the Brazilian national team. A funny thing will happen. You will actually show up to your first training camp a day later than your teammates. Why? Youâ€™ll be delayed by a match with GrÃªmio in the final of the Campeonato GaÃºcho tournament against Internacional.

Playing for Internacional will be the captain of the â€™94 World Cup team, Dunga.

You will play very well in this match. So when you arrive to the pitch for your first day of training with Brazil, your new teammates â€” the guys you watched win the â€™94 World Cup â€” will be talking about one player: the small kid wearing number 10.

Theyâ€™ll be talking about you.

Theyâ€™ll be talking about how you dribbled past Dunga. Theyâ€™ll be talking about your title-winning goal. But donâ€™t get too confident, because theyâ€™re not going to go easy on you. This will be the most important moment of your life. When you get to this level, people will expect many things of you.

Will you keep playing your way?

Or will you start to calculate? Will you play it safe?

The only advice I have to give you is this: Do it your way. Be free. Hear the music. This is the only way for you to live your life.

Playing for Brazil will change your life. All of a sudden, doors you never even knew were available to you will start to open.

Youâ€™ll start to think about playing in Europe, where a lot of your heroes went to prove themselves. Ronaldo will tell you about life in Barcelona. Youâ€™ll see his awards, his Ballon dâ€™Or, his club trophies. Suddenly, youâ€™ll want to make history too. You will start to dream beyond GrÃªmio. In 2001, you will sign with Paris Saint-Germain.

How can I tell a kid who was born in a wooden house in a favela what life will be like in Europe? Itâ€™s impossible. You will not understand, even if I tell you. From the time you leave for Paris, then Barcelona, then Milan, everything will go by very, very fast. Some of the media in Europe will not understand your style of play. They will not understand why you are always smiling.

Well, you are smiling because football is fun. Why would you be serious? Your goal is to spread joy. Iâ€™ll say it again â€” creativity over calculation.

Stay free, and youâ€™ll win a World Cup for Brazil.

Stay free, and youâ€™ll win the Champions League, La Liga and Serie A.

Stay free, and youâ€™ll win a Ballon dâ€™Or.

What youâ€™ll be most proud of, though, is helping to change football in Barcelona through your style of play. When you arrive there, Real Madrid will be the power of Spanish football. By the time you leave the club, kids will be dreaming of playing â€œthe Barcelona way.â€

Listen to me, though. Your role in this will be about much more than what you do on the pitch.

At Barcelona, youâ€™ll hear about this kid on the youth team. He wears number 10 like you. Heâ€™s small like you. He plays with the ball like you. You and your teammates will go watch him play for Barcelonaâ€™s youth squad, and at that moment youâ€™ll know heâ€™s going to be more than a great footballer. The kid is different. His name is Leo Messi.

Youâ€™ll tell the coaches to bring him up to play with you on the senior side. When he arrives, the Barcelona players will be talking about him like the Brazilian players were talking about you.

I want you to give him one piece of advice.

Tell him, â€œPlay with happiness. Play free. Just play with the ball.â€

Even when you are gone, the free style will live on in Barcelona through Messi.

A lot will happen in your life, good and bad. But everything that happens, you will owe to football. When people question your style, or why you smile after you lose a match, I want you to think of one memory.

When your father leaves this earth, you wonâ€™t have any movies of him. Your family doesnâ€™t have much money, so your parents donâ€™t own a video camera. You wonâ€™t be able to hear your fatherâ€™s voice, or hear him laughing again.

But among his possessions, there is one thing youâ€™ll always have to remember him by. Itâ€™s a photo of you and him playing football together. You are smiling, happy â€” with the ball at your feet. He is happy watching you.

When the money comes â€” and the pressure, and the critics â€” stay free.

Play as he told you to play.

Play with the ball.

â€”Ronaldinho

Dear Edson (or Dico, as your family likes to call you),

Listen very carefully.

When your family moves away from TrÃªs CoraÃ§Ãµes, donâ€™t forget the socks of your mother. You are young, only five years old, but you must not forget the socks. If you forget them, your life may be very different.

You and your family will move to a very small town called Bauru. You will move to this place because of your father. You see, he plays for the football club Bauru AtlÃ©tico. In Bauru, your family has a very simple house. You and your brother share the same bed. This is not always comfortable, but because of this, the two of you will become very good friends.

In front of the house, there is no grass. Only dirt and sand. This is your first football pitch. Many larger ones will come. I will tell you more about this later. For now, the front of your house is your stadium. You and your friends cut sticks and bamboo with sharp knives to make the goals.

You do not have the money to buy a real ball. This is why you must never forget the socks. There is very little money in the family. So, you make a ball by stuffing old newspapers inside the socks.

The ball, itâ€™s not always round. But thatâ€™s O.K. You and your friends will play for hours outside, and you are called â€œThe Shoeless Onesâ€ because you cannot afford football boots, either. You will quickly learn to go around the puddles. The biggest danger is water, and the puddles will be your first defenders.

You may need to put this letter down and go call your mother to say sorry. Because you will take many of her socks over the years!

Ah, your mother. She is a very tough woman. As Iâ€™m writing this, she is nearly 99 years old. She still teases you to this day. When you visit her, donâ€™t tell her what you wish to talk about. She says, â€œYou are inÂ myÂ house. We discussÂ myÂ things.â€

She is always the boss in the house. Your father is often away with the football club. She is the one who saves the money and makes sure you, your brother and eventually your sister, have books and shoes. She will teach you very important lessons. Thereâ€™s one lesson that you will remember for a long time. It is the lesson about your neighbor, the one with the mango tree.

One day, you bring home a mango from her tree.

Your mother asks, â€œDico, where did you get this mango?â€

You say, â€œI got it from Donna Maria across the street.â€

â€œBut you asked her for it?â€

â€œYes, yes, of course.â€

This is a lie.

She says, â€œO.K. Dico, letâ€™s go ask Donna Maria if this is true.â€

Sometimes, you are a bad boy. When you are older, you will remember this and become very embarrassed. But this is the most important lesson your mother will teach you. Itâ€™s not about mangoes, Edson. Itâ€™s about respecting other people.

Now, letâ€™s talk about your father. Many times, he will watch you play in the street. You score one, two, three, sometimes four goals. But your father is not happy about the goals. He tells you that you have to do better.

What? You do not understand.

He says, â€œNo, no, no, what I mean is that you need to learn to do the other things. You must have many skills on the pitch. Not just scoring goals.â€

This is very important advice. Remember this always. Later on, your life will change. But he will tell you the same exact thing when you play at Santos Football Club.

(It is true, Edson! You will become a professional player. Stay calm. I will tell you more later.)

After the match, your father will say, â€œYou made two or three bad passes. Why?â€

â€œBut father, we won 4â€“1.â€

He will tell you again, â€œYou must be precise. You can get better.â€

You see, your father, he is a competitive man. He once scored five headers in a game. This is a record in Brazil. When you score your 1,000th goal at the MaracanÃ£, it will be a penalty kick, and the entire world will stop for one moment to watch (this is your gift from God). The atmosphere in the stadium will be one big party, no matter what team the fans support. You will receive a trophy. There will be many photographs. This will go down in the history books. During the celebration, your father will whisper to you, â€œI have scored five headers in one game, but have you?â€

You will both laugh. Your father, he is a very special man, and he is the only reason why you chose to play football. Even after his career-ending injury, you will always consider him the best player. All you want to do is be like your father.

You will never score five headers in a match, but you will score so many goals (1,283 to be exact), that you become known all over the world by the name â€œPelÃ©.â€

PelÃ©? Who is PelÃ©? Your name is Edson, and your parents named you after Thomas Edison, the American inventor.

I know you are very proud of your name, Edson Arantes do Nascimento.

But cherish it now, because you will not have it much longer.

You see, there is a goalkeeper for Bauru. His name is BilÃ©. You say to your friends one day at school, â€œDid you hear of the save by PelÃ©?â€

Your friends will laugh and say, â€œHis name is BilÃ©, not PelÃ©.â€

They tease you and start calling you PelÃ©. This makes you very angry. One day, you will get so mad that you fight them. The school suspends you for two days. When your mother hears of this? Oh, no â€¦ you poor boy.

From this day on, you will be known as PelÃ© forever. But never ever forget the boy named Edson. Always remember that boy in your heart and in your mind.

When you turn 13 years old, you will play football more seriously. This is the start of something incredible for you. You start to train with the youth team at Bauru, the team of your father. This is also where you get your first job, cleaning the boots of the senior team players. They give you one or two coins for every pair. Not much money, but enough for you to buy a real ball. No more socks!

You will do very well as a young football player. A gentleman named Waldemar De Brito will come into your life. He is a very important person for starting your career at Santos Football Club. After scouting your talent, he will say to you:

â€œPelÃ©, I believe you can be a very, very good professional. But do not ever think you are the best. Do not ever think you are God. If you make money, save some of it for the future. Do not start to buy cigars and candy. You must stay the boy from Bauru.â€

Remember these words. Because you will become a professional at the age of 15. Of course, you are just a boy. When you walk into the locker room at Santos for the first time, you will watch your teammates putting on their boots. You are in awe. They are grown men. You look at your shirt number. It is number 10.

You think,Â My, God. What am I doing here?Â (This memory will stay with you forever.)

The director of the club will say, â€œCome here, PelÃ©. Put on your Santos shirt for a photograph.â€

There are so many light bulb flashes. And you are so skinny that the shirt looks very funny on you. The director says, â€œThe day after tomorrow, the picture will be in the newspapers.â€

You tell your father, â€œI took a picture in the number 10 Santos shirt â€” I think they like me!â€

Yes, you are still that little boy from Bauru.

Let me tell you another funny story.

Santos is a very long journey from your home. You need to ride the train for five hours from Bauru to the capital of SÃ£o Paolo. Then you need to take the bus for two more hours to get to Santos. (Bring books to read, Edson. Donâ€™t just sleep.)

One day at the bus stop in Santos, you are supposed to meet your father. You wait and wait and wait for him. You get very thirsty in the heat, so you take a walk to the beach. The water looks so clear. You dip your hand in and take a drink.

Ach!

It tastes of salt. You spit it out.

You think,Â What is wrong with this water?Â Is it poison?

You will laugh at this some day, I promise. You see, in Bauru, you never saw the beach, the sand, the sea. But in Santos, there is a beautiful blue ocean. It is the first time you will see ever see the ocean.

Do not drink the ocean, Edson!

On the football pitch in Santos, you are much more comfortable. You will play for Santos Football Club for nearly two decades, and during this time you will get many proposals to join clubs in Milan, Madrid â€” all over the world. This may sound incredible to you now, but listen to my words: Do not take the proposals.

I tell you again: Do notÂ everÂ take the proposals. You will have many other opportunities to go abroad in your life, I promise.

For what reason would you leave Santos? TheÂ PeixeÂ is near and dear to your heart. You and your teammates will make Santos one of the best clubs â€” not just in Brazil or South America, but in the world. The team will win the Continental Treble in 1962. There will be many Brazilian championships. You will travel places and play friendly matches all over the world. Because of you, the two sides in a civil war in Congo will call a cease-fire just to watch your team play.

You will have incredible journeys with Santos, and you will still remain close to your family. I ask again: Why would you leave Santos?

You will also begin to play for your country. It is an incredible honor for you. When you are only 17 years old, you will travel on an airplane for the very first time to Sweden for the 1958 World Cup. Many things are different in Sweden. At that time, battery-powered radio will be brand new. They donâ€™t have this in Brazil yet.

One day, the team will visit a shop in the city and your teammate, Garrincha, will hear a strange voice coming from the radio. You hold up the radio in amazement. The radio man is speaking Swedish.

Garrincha says, â€œPelÃ©, why do you listen to this nonsense?â€

You say, â€œIt is incredible. I wish to buy it.â€

He says, â€œNo, no, do not buy this. You will not understand what the voices say!â€

Garrincha does not know that when you bring the radio back home, the radio signal in Brazil will be in Portuguese!

Oh, you will laugh and laugh when Garrincha realizes this.

But when you travel the world with Brazil, there will be another surprise. And this one will make you sad.

You think everybody knows your country, but this is not the case. At this time, many people do not know where Brazil is on a map. They will say, â€œOh, Brazil, this is in Argentina, no?â€ You will smile, but inside you will be sad that people do not know your country, your home.

But donâ€™t worry too much. After the final of the 1958 World Cup, they will know.

This is because you will lift the trophy.

It is true.

This will be the first of three World Cup championships for you.

At the end of the â€™58 final, you will pass out and fall to the ground. Even today, this is a moment that is difficult to explain. The emotion is simply too much for your body.

When your teammates wake you up, you will cry. You always cry, Edson, even later in life. You are an emotional person who cries easily.

Winning the World Cup is not just a dream for you, itâ€™s a dream for your country. And to win it at only 17 years old. You are so young. And you will be the youngest World Cup champion in the history of the sport. Thank God for this victory, because you will not always be young.

In 1970, you will cry again because it will be your final World Cup. These are different tears. This will be more difficult for you emotionally. You must ask God to help you. You cannot lose for your country in your final chance.

What will happen? I will not tell you. Some things cannot be explained, even from the future.

When your career with Santos and the Brazilian National Team is over, you will have a unique opportunity to play in America. Not just anywhere in America â€” New York City, with a team called the Cosmos. This opportunity, you must take. It is very important to grow the game in America.

Before I leave you, I want to talk for a moment about beauty. You will see many beautiful things in your career. When you run to the crowd after scoring a goal, you see the faces of people crying with joy.

This moment shows you how much you mean to the people.

But there is one moment above all that you will remember forever. In 1968, you will play a match in Colombia.

During the match, your teammate Coutinho and a Colombian player start to fight. Many players will run over to try to stop the fight. When things have calmed down, the referee will give you the red card.

You will tell him, â€œNo, no, I did not fight. I tried to help.â€ But still, the referee forces you off the field. He thinks you did it because you look similar to Coutinho.

You leave the pitch in anger and walk to the locker room. Then, when you take off your boots, you start to hear noise. The crowd is yelling about something.

Your coach runs into the locker room and says, â€œPelÃ©, come back! You have to come back!â€

You say, â€œWhat? I am not allowed to go back. I got a red card.â€

Your coach says, â€œNo, you do not understand. Do not take off your boots. The crowd, they started to make noise. They have made a protest!â€

This is the first and only time in your life that you will see something like this. The Colombian crowd has seen the mistake. They are chanting for PelÃ© to come back.

The referee who makes the mistake is substituted with a new referee. Never in football do they take the referee out and let the player return to the pitch. You see, the crowd has such a passion for the beautiful game. They donâ€™t care that you are the opponent.

You come back to the pitch, and the crowd roars.

This moment shows you how much you mean to the people.

Do you see? God has given you a brilliant life.

Pray to Him:Â Take care of my family. You need to take care of one another. This I promise you.

But there is another thing I want you to pray for every night. This is more difficult to explain. In Brazil, the people are beautiful. We have amazing food, music, culture. But we have many problems. There is crime and poverty. Yes, even to this day when I write to you, Edson, our country still suffers.

You must pray to God:Â Please make things better in Brazil. There are still kids in Brazil playing football barefoot in the streets. There are still kids not able to afford a ball. There are still kids in Brazil stealing mangoes. This is very sad. Football cannot give to everyone what it gave to you.

What is your magic moment? It was when you were born. Because you have an excellent family that has taught and treated you well. And this is why, when you travel all over the world, the door is always open to welcome you. The people of the world gave you the greatest love, and you must do your best to give it back.

Remain the boy from Brazil. Remain Edson. And remember these three words: honesty, patience and respect.

Keep the ball rolling,

Edson Arantes do Nascimento

2016

***

The movie â€œPelÃ©: Birth of a Legendâ€ is now available on Amazon and iTunes

I remember the exact moment I knew we were broke. I can still picture my mum at the refrigerator and the look on her face.

I was six years old, and I came home for lunch during our break at school. My mum had the same thing on the menu every single day: Bread and milk. When youâ€™re a kid, you donâ€™t even think about it. But I guess thatâ€™s what we could afford.

Then this one day I came home, and I walked into the kitchen, and I saw my mum at the refrigerator with the box of milk, like normal. But this time she was mixing something in with it. She was shaking it all up, you know? I didnâ€™t understand what was going on. Then she brought my lunch over to me, and she was smiling like everything was cool. But I realized right away what was going on.

She was mixing water in with the milk. We didnâ€™t have enough money to make it last the whole week. We were broke. Not just poor, but broke.

My father had been a pro footballer, but he was at the end of his career and the money was all gone. The first thing to go was the cable TV. No more football. No more Match of the Day. No signal.

Then Iâ€™d come home at night and the lights would be shut off. No electricity for two, three weeks at a time.

Then Iâ€™d want to take a bath, and there would be no hot water. My mum would heat up a kettle on the stove, and Iâ€™d stand in the shower splashing the warm water on top of my head with a cup.

There were even times when my mum had to â€œborrowâ€ bread from the bakery down the street. The bakers knew me and my little brother, so theyâ€™d let her take a loaf of bread on Monday and pay them back on Friday.

I knew we were struggling. But when she was mixing in water with the milk, I realized it was over, you know what I mean? This was our life.

I didnâ€™t say a word. I didnâ€™t want her to stress. I just ate my lunch. But I swear to God, I made a promise to myself that day. It was like somebody snapped their fingers and woke me up. I knew exactly what I had to do, and what I was going to do.

I couldnâ€™t see my mother living like that. Nah, nah, nah. I couldnâ€™t have that.

People in football love to talk about mental strength. Well, Iâ€™m the strongest dude youâ€™re ever going to meet. Because I remember sitting in the dark with my brother and my mom, saying our prayers, and thinking, believing, knowing â€¦ itâ€™s going to happen.

I kept my promise to myself for a while. But then some days Iâ€™d come home from school and find my mum crying. So I finally told her one day, â€œMum, itâ€™s gonna change. Youâ€™ll see. Iâ€™m going to play football for Anderlecht, and itâ€™s going to happen soon. Weâ€™ll be good. You wonâ€™t have to worry anymore.â€

I was six.

I asked my father, â€œWhen can you start playing professional football?â€

He said, â€œSixteen.â€

I said, â€œO.K., sixteen then.â€

It was going to happen. Period.

Let me tell you something â€” every game I ever played was a Final. When I played in the park, it was a Final. When I played during break in kindergarten, it was a Final. Iâ€™m dead-ass serious. I used to try to tear the cover off the ball every time I shot it. Full power. We werenâ€™t hitting R1, bro. No finesse shot. I didnâ€™t have the new FIFA. I didnâ€™t have a Playstation. I wasnâ€™t playing around. I was trying to kill you.

When I started growing taller, some of the teachers and the parents would be stressing me. Iâ€™ll never forget the first time I heard one of the adults say, â€œHey, how old are you? What year were you born?â€

Iâ€™m like, What? Are you serious?

When I was 11 years old, I was playing for the LiÃ¨rse youth team, and one of the parents from the other team literally tried to stop me from going on the pitch. He was like, â€œHow old is this kid? Where is his I.D.? Where is he from?â€

I thought, Where am I from? What? I was born in Antwerp. Iâ€™m from Belgium.

My dad wasnâ€™t there, because he didnâ€™t have a car to drive to my away games. I was all alone, and I had to stand up for myself. I went and got my I.D. from my bag and showed it to all the parents, and they were passing it around inspecting it, and I remember the blood just rushing through me â€¦ and I thought, â€œOh, Iâ€™m gonna kill your son even more now. I was already going to kill him, but now Iâ€™m gonna destroy him. Youâ€™re gonna drive the boy home crying now.â€

I wanted to be the best footballer in Belgian history. That was my goal. Not good. Not great. The best. I played with so much anger, because of a lot of things â€¦ because of the rats running around in our apartment â€¦ because I couldnâ€™t watch the Champions League â€¦ because of how the other parents used to look at me.

I was on a mission.

When I was 12, I scored 76 goals in 34 games.

I scored them all wearing my dadâ€™s shoes. Once our feet got to be the same size, we used to share.

One day I called up my grandfather â€” my mumâ€™s dad. He was one of the most important people in my life. He was my connection back to Congo, where my mum and dad are from. So I was on the phone with him one day, and I said, â€œYeah, Iâ€™m doing really well. I scored 76 goals, and we won the league. The big teams are noticing me.â€

And usually, he always wanted to hear about my football. But this time it was strange. He said, â€œYeah, Rom. Yeah, thatâ€™s great. But can you do me a favor?â€

I said, â€œYeah, what is it?â€

He said, â€œCan you look after my daughter, please?â€

I remember being so confused. Like, whatâ€™s Grandad on about?

I said, â€œMum? Yeah, weâ€™re cool. Weâ€™re O.K.â€

He said, â€œNo, promise me. Can you promise me? Just look after my daughter. Just look after her for me, O.K.?â€

I said, â€œYeah, Granddad. I got it. I promise you.â€

Five days later he passed away. And then I understood what he really meant.

It makes me so sad to think about, because I just wish that he could have lived another four years to see me play for Anderlecht. To see that I kept my promise, you know? To see that everything was going to be O.K.

I told my mum that I would make it at 16.

I was late by 11 days.

May 24, 2009.

The playoff final. Anderlecht vs. Standard LiÃ¨ge.

That was the craziest day of my life. But we have to back up for a minute. Because at the start of the season, I was barely playing for the Anderlecht U-19s. The coach had me coming off the bench. Iâ€™m like, â€œHow the hell am I going to sign a pro contract on my 16th birthday if Iâ€™m still on the bench for the U-19s?â€

So I made a bet with our coach.

I told him, â€œIâ€™ll guarantee you something. If you actually play me, Iâ€™m going to score 25 goals by December.â€

He laughed. He literally laughed at me.

I said, â€œLetâ€™s make a bet then.â€

He said, â€œO.K., but if you donâ€™t score 25 by December, youâ€™re going to the bench.â€

I said, â€œFine, but if I win, youâ€™re going to clean all the minivans that take the players home from training.â€

He said, â€œO.K., itâ€™s a deal.â€

I said, â€œAnd one more thing. You have to make pancakes for us every day.â€

He said, â€œO.K., fine.â€

That was the dumbest bet that man ever made.

I had 25 by November. We were eating pancakes before Christmas, bro.

Let that be a lesson. You donâ€™t play around with a boy whoâ€™s hungry!

I signed my pro contract with Anderlecht on my birthday, May 13. Went straight out and bought the new FIFA and a cable package. It was already the end of the season, so I was at home chilling. Dear 17-year-old Gianluigi,

I write this letter to you tonight as a 41-year-old man who has experienced many, many things in life, and has made some mistakes. I have some good news and some bad news for you.Â The truth is that I am really here to speak to you about your soul.

Yes, your soul. You do have one, believe it or not.Â

Letâ€™s begin with the bad news. Youâ€™re 17 years old. Youâ€™re about to become a real footballer, like in your dreams. You think that you know everything. But the truth is, my friend, you donâ€™t know shit.Â

In just a few days, you will get the chance to start your first Serie A match for Parma, and you donâ€™t know enough to be scared. You should be in bed, drinking warm milk. But what are you going to do? Youâ€™re going to go to the nightclub with your good friend from the Primavera.Â

Youâ€™re just going to have one beer, right?Â

But then you exaggerate a bit. You play the movie character. The strongman. This is how you usually cope with this pressure that you donâ€™t even know that you feel. Soon, youâ€™ll be outside the club, arguing with some police officers at one in the morning.Â

Just go home. Go to bed.Â

And please, I beg you, donâ€™t piss on the wheel of the police car. The officers will not find it amusing, the club will not find it amusing, and you will risk everything that youâ€™ve worked for.Â

This is the kind of chaos that you bring upon yourself, for no reason. There is a burning inside you that will lead you to make mistakes. Of course, you think that you are showing your teammates that youâ€™re strong and free, but in reality, this is a mask that you wear.

In just a few days, you will be gifted with three things that are very, very intoxicating, but also very, very dangerous.Â

Money, fame, and the job of your dreams.Â

Now, youâ€™re surely thinking,Â What could possibly be dangerous about this?Â

Well, this is a paradox.Â

On one hand, itâ€™s true that a keeper needs confidence. He needs to be fearless. If you give a manager the choice between the greatest technical keeper in the world, and the most fearless keeper in the world, I guarantee you that he will choose the fearless bastard every single time.Â

On the other hand, a person who is fearless can easily forget that they have a mind. If you live your life in a nihilistic way, thinking only about football, your soul will start to wither. Eventually, you will become so depressed that you wonâ€™t even want to leave your bed.Â

You can laugh if you want, but this will happen to you. It will happen at the height of your career, when you have everything a man could ever want in life. You will be 26 years old. The keeper of Juventus and the Italian national team. You will have money and respect. People will even call you Superman.

But youâ€™re no superhero. Youâ€™re just a man like anyone else. And the truth is that the pressure of this profession can turn you into a robot. Your routine can become a prison. You go to training. You come home and watch TV. You go to sleep. You do the same the next day. You win. You lose. It repeats and repeats.Â

One morning, when you get out of bed to go to training, your legs will start shaking uncontrollably. You will be so weak that you wonâ€™t be able to drive your car. Initially, you will think itâ€™s just fatigue, or a virus. But then it will get worse. All youâ€™ll want to do is sleep. At training, every save will feel like a titanic effort. For seven months, you will have a hard time finding joy in life.

At this moment, we must pause.Â

Because I know what youâ€™re thinking reading this, at 17 years old.Â

You are saying, â€œHow is this possible? I am a happy person. I am a born leader. If I will be the keeper for Juventus, making millions, then I must be happy. It is impossible to be depressed.â€Â

Well, I must ask you an important question.Â WhyÂ did you decide to devote your life to football, Gigi? Do you remember?Â

And, please, do not just say that it was because of Thomas Nâ€™Kono. You must go deeper than that. You have to remember every detail.Â

You were 12, yes.Â

The 1990 World Cup was in Italy, yes.Â

The first match was Argentina vs. Cameroon at the San Siro, yes.Â

But where were you during the first match? Close your eyes. You were in your living room, all alone. Why werenâ€™t your friends there, like usual? You canâ€™t recall. Your grandmother was in the kitchen, making lunch. And it was so hot that day that she shut all the windows to make the room more fresh. It was completely dark, except for the yellow glow of the television.Â

What do you see?Â

You see this strange name. CAMEROON.Â

You donâ€™t know where Cameroon is. You didnâ€™t even know such a place existed before this moment. Of course, you know Argentina and Maradona, but there is something magical about the players from Cameroon. Itâ€™s so hot under the summer sun, but their keeper is still wearing a full suit. Long black pants. Long green shirt with the pink collar. The way he moves, the way he stands tall, the fantastic mustache. He captivates your heart in a way that is unexplainable.

He is the coolest man you have ever seen.

The commentator says his name is Thomas Nâ€™Kono.Â

Then, magic.Â

Thereâ€™s a corner for Argentina, and Thomas runs out into the crowd and punches the ball 30 yards in the air. This is the moment that you know what you want to do with your life.

You do not want to be simply a goalkeeper.Â

You want to beÂ thisÂ kind of goalkeeper.Â

You want to be wild, courageous, free.Â

Minute after minute, watching this match, you become who you are. Your life is being written. Cameroon scores, and you become so nervous for them to hang on that you cannot physically take it anymore. You leap off the couch. You spend the entire second half pacing around the television stand. When Cameroon has a second man sent off, you cannot even bear to listen.Â

For the final five minutes, you crouch behind the television with the sound off.

You peek out every once in a while to see whatâ€™s happening, then retreat.Â

Finally, you peek out, and the Cameroon players are celebrating. You run straight out into the street. Two other kids from your neighborhood do the same thing. Everyone is yelling, â€œDid you see Cameroon? Did you see Cameroon?â€Â

That day, a fire is born inside of you. Cameroon is a place that exists. Thomas Nâ€™Kono is a man who exists. You will show the world that Buffon exists.Â

ThisÂ is why you became a footballer. Not because of money or fame. Because of the artistry and style of this man Thomas Nâ€™Kono. Because of hisÂ soul.Â

You must remember this: money and fame isnâ€™t the purpose. If you are not taking care of your soul, if you are not looking for inspiration in things outside of football, you will deteriorate. If I could give you one piece of advice, it is to be much more curious about the world around you when you are still young. You will save yourself, and especially your family, a lot of heartache.Â

To be a keeper is to be courageous, it is true.Â

But to be courageous is not to be ignorant, Gigi.

At the depths of your depression, something strange and beautiful will happen. One morning, you will decide to break your routine and go to a different restaurant in Torino for breakfast. So youâ€™ll take a new route through the city, and youâ€™ll walk past an art museum.Â

The poster outside will say CHAGALL.Â

You have heard this name before. But you donâ€™t know about art.Â

You have things to do.Â

You must be on your way.Â

You are Buffon.Â

But who is Buffon?Â

WhoÂ areÂ you, really?

Do you know?

This is the most important part of this letter. YouÂ haveÂ to walk into that museum, on that specific day. It will be the most important decision of your life.Â

If you do not walk into that museum, and you carry on with your life as a footballer, as Superman, then you will continue to lock all of your feelings away in the cellar, and your soul will deteriorate.Â

But if you go inside, you will see hundreds of paintings by Chagall. Most of them will do nothing to stir you. Some good, some interesting, some that say nothing to you at all.Â

But then you will see one specific painting that will hit you like a lightning bolt.Â

It is calledÂ The Walk.

Itâ€™s an almost childlike image. A man and a woman are in a park, having a picnic, but everything is magical. The woman is flying away into the sky, like an angel, and the man is standing on the ground, holding her hand, smiling.Â

It is like the dream of a child.Â

This image will transmit something from another world. It will give you the feeling of a child. The feeling of happiness in simplicity.Â

The feeling of Thomas Nâ€™Kono punching the ball 30 yards.Â

The feeling of your grandmother calling to you from the kitchen.Â

The feeling of sitting behind the television in the dark, praying.Â

As we get older, we can easily forget these feelings.Â

You must go back to the museum the very next day. It is essential.Â

The woman at the ticket booth will look at you in a funny way. Sheâ€™ll say, â€œWerenâ€™t you just here yesterday?â€Â

It doesnâ€™t matter. Go back inside. This art will be the best cure for you. When you open up your mind, the inner heaviness that you feel will be lifted, like the woman being lifted into the air in Chagallâ€™s painting.

There is an incredible irony in this moment. Sometimes I think that life must be written for us. So many unexplainable and beautiful things that will happen to you that seem to be connected. This is one of them.Â

Because when you are a young player for Parma, you will do something out of ignorance that will mark you. Before a big match, youâ€™ll want to make a big gesture to show your teammates and the fans that you are a leader, you are courageous, you are a big character.Â

So you will write a message on your shirt that you once saw carved on a desk when you were at school.Â

Youâ€™ll write, â€œDeath to Cowards.â€Â

You think itâ€™s just a motivational cry.Â

You donâ€™t know that it is a slogan of the far-right fascists.Â

This is one of the mistakes thatÂ will cause your family a lot of pain. But these mistakes are important, because they remind you that youâ€™re human. They will remind you, again and again, that you donâ€™t know shit, my friend. This is good, because football will do an excellent job of trying to convince you that you are special. But you must remember that you are no different from the bartender or the electrician, who you will be friends with for life.Â

This is what will get you out of your depression. Not remembering that you are special, but remembering that you are theÂ sameÂ as everyone else. You cannot comprehend this now, at 17 years old, but I promise you that real courage is showing weakness and not being ashamed.Â

You deserve the gift of life, Gigi. Just as everyone does. Remember this.Â

Things are connected in ways that you are too young and naive to see now. My only regret is that you did not open your mind to the world sooner. Perhaps this is just who you are. At 41 years old, you will still feel this burning inside. You will still not be satisfied, I am sorry to say. Even holding the World Cup trophy in your arms will not soothe this feeling. Until you have a season where you donâ€™t let in any goals, you will not be content.Â

Yes, perhaps it is true that you have always been this way.Â

Do you remember the first winter you went to visit your uncle in Udine, up in the mountains? Or is this a memory that only an older man can recall?Â

You were four years old. It had snowed overnight. You had never seen snow before. You woke up and looked out the window, and you saw a dream. This whole country turned white.Â

You ran outside in your pajamas, and you didnâ€™t even understand what snow was. But there was no hesitation. You looked at the white snowbank, and what did you do? Did you think? Did you wonder? Did you run inside for your coat?Â

No, you jumped right in. Fearless.Â

Your grandmother was screaming, â€œGianluigi!!!!!!!!!! No! No! No!â€Â

You were soaking wet, grinning.Â

You ended up having a fever for a whole week.Â

But you didnâ€™t give a damn.Â

No hesitation. Right into the snow.Â

This is who you are.Â

You are Buffon.Â

You will show the world that you exist.Â

Dear 16-year-old Arjen,

Itâ€™s Thursday afternoon, and momâ€™s been phoning your school.

And phoning.

And phoning.

At first, youâ€™re going to think something is wrong. Why wouldnâ€™t you? Momâ€™s never tried to get a hold of you while youâ€™re in class.

First off, donâ€™t worry. Everything is fine. In fact, youâ€™ll find out things are more than fine. But youâ€™re not going to believe what sheâ€™s going to tell you when you call her back. Youâ€™re not going to see this one coming.

When you call her back during a break between classes, everything is about to change. Very quickly.

So before you do call her back, and before everything happens, let me just say one thing that I want you to keep with you: Always play football with the hunger youâ€™ve had. Keep your drive to improve. To do more. To be the best.

Remember that, will you? For everything thatâ€™s about to happen, never forget that hunger.

â€œThe coach of Groningenâ€™s first team called earlier,â€ Mom will tell you, once you finally speak. â€œHe wants you to travel with them this weekend for the match.â€

I know, right? Incredible.

Why do I bring this up? Well, Iâ€™ve been thinking about that moment a lot lately. The moment when things really started. Another season has finished â€” your 17th, with another one coming this week. Youâ€™re 33, and youâ€™re only playing on a one-year contract, so after that, who knows?

And maybe when the end of your career becomes more and more of a reality â€¦ you start thinking about the beginning. When it stopped being just a game.

That happened when you arrived to Groningen. And Groningen will be an opportunity that will take you to PSV, and then PSV will take you to Chelsea. At 20 years old, youâ€™ll be in the Premier League.

And your boss? His name is JosÃ© Mourinho. I should prepare you. Because he will expect a lot of you â€¦ and of everyone. Right away, youâ€™ll feel the difference in playing for a Premier League club. Youâ€™ll need to be tougher, stronger, faster.

Youâ€™ll have to prove yourself all over again once you get there. And prove yourself to JosÃ© every single week to stay in the lineup. Look, a lot has been said about JosÃ©. Heâ€™s a strong personality, heâ€™s demanding. But ever since you started playing, youâ€™ve been just as demanding of yourself. In a way, itâ€™ll almost seem like a perfect match. He wants to see your very best, each and every day on the pitch. And all youâ€™ll want to give is your best. Whether in training, or in a match.

Or working your way back from an injury.

Yes, this is going to be the first time youâ€™re challenged in that way, too. Itâ€™s not how you wanted to start off in England â€¦ with a broken bone in your foot in a preseason match. Youâ€™ll be sidelined for more than two months. But that will only provide more motivation to prove yourself. To prove yourself to JosÃ©. To your teammates. To Stamford Bridge and the fans.

Youâ€™ll want to show everyone what you can do.

And you will, with a 72nd-minute goal in your very first start at Stamford Bridge in November 2004.

Itâ€™ll be right in front of the box, off your left foot.

(And by the way, your left foot? Specifically, coming in from the right wing and shooting with your left? Work on this. Practice this. Itâ€™ll come in handy more times than you can count. Trust me on this one.)

Itâ€™ll only be two years, but Chelsea will be an important step for you. For your manager, for dealing with injuries â€” but, also, that team will be something special. I give credit to JosÃ© on this, he knows how to create and build a team. And this team? Well, it was a good one.

Not just because you had players like Lampard and Drogba and ÄŒech and Terry on the pitch.

But because you had players like Lampard and Drogba and ÄŒech and Terry off the pitch as well.

Everyone on that team was thinking about each other. Everyone was thinking about the club. The atmosphere during that time â€¦ it was amazing. A lot of the guys who have been at the club for a while will look out for you, but there will be no one more important â€” not only for you, but for everyone â€” than John Terry.

What can a Dutch winger learn from an English center back?

Everything.

The most important thing though, is what it takes to be a captain and a leader at a club. Heâ€™ll be someone you can talk to, whether about football or anything else. Heâ€™ll be someone who gives advice, who encourages you. Learn as much from him as you can. How he gives everything for the club. How he gives everything for the team â€” from the first to the last minute. Out there, heâ€™s taking care of every team member. And he does the same off the pitch as well.

Iâ€™m not sure youâ€™ll know it then, just how much John influenced you. So really take in those moments with him. You wonâ€™t play with anyone quite like him again.

Or have an experience quite like you had at Chelsea. There were titles and cups in Holland, but at Chelsea, youâ€™ll all be part of history. The first league title in 50 years. Itâ€™s not going to feel complete at the time because youâ€™ll be injured. But enjoy that moment more than I did then. Appreciate it properly â€” because you were a part of that team, you were important and you did do your job.

And then help the team win another title the year after.

And then?

There will be the next stepâ€¦.

Real Madrid.

In England, youâ€™ll see from your very first match: The fans are living and breathing football. But in Spain, itâ€™s just â€¦ different. They donâ€™t breathe and live football, itâ€™s just â€¦ life.

But then, after two years, youâ€™re going to find out that football is also â€¦ business.

And youâ€™re not going to be happy about it.

See, up until this point, everything has made sense. From being a boy playing at school and on little pitches, to Groningen, to PSV, to Chelsea, to Real Madridâ€¦. To league titles and cups and Champions League semi-finals.

All of it, it was always about moving forward, about improving, about finding a new challenge.

It was always about taking the next step. Thatâ€™s how you wanted to play your game.

But Bayern? Youâ€™ll see it as a step backward. Of course, they have the league titles and the cup titles, but for you, right now, itâ€™s about winning a Champions League, for which Bayern havenâ€™t been favorites. At Chelsea and at Real Madrid, you didnâ€™t get there, either.

And I know what youâ€™ll be be thinking when you hear about this move: Now I definitely wonâ€™t get there.

Real Madrid was the biggest club in the world at the time. And youâ€™ll feel that, with them, youâ€™re at the top of the mountain, and anything else is a step down.

But hereâ€™s something I want you to know: You couldnâ€™t be more wrong about anything in your life.

Because coming to Bayern will be the best decision you will ever make.

Youâ€™ll be a part of something more at Bayern. Because success wonâ€™t just be on the pitch, but on all levels. Youâ€™ll see. Financially. Globally. In Germany and across Europe â€” that badge and those colors will mean something.

No one will expect you to do it, but the team will make it to the finals of the Champions League in your first year.

Youâ€™ll get knocked out early in 2011, but by the next year â€¦ it will be Bayernâ€™s moment. The 2012 Champions League final, in front of your home crowd at the Allianz Arena. Against your former club, Chelsea.

It couldnâ€™t have been written any better.

Except â€¦ and I donâ€™t know how to tell you this, but â€¦ it turns into a nightmare.

A lot will be said about that final, what you couldâ€™ve done â€¦ what you didnâ€™t do. But thereâ€™s something else that people wonâ€™t write about or see. And that was the first day back at training, a few weeks later. To be honest, you were ready to get back to training the day after the final. But maybe that time is something you all needed. Because when you do go back thereâ€™s â€¦ a feeling.

Youâ€™ve had plenty first days back in your career. And they all go the same way. Everyoneâ€™s lightly getting back into the rhythm, OK, here we goâ€¦

But not this time. This time it was actually more than just a feeling, it was a spirit. Everybody wanted something. One thing, really.

Revenge.

And every match, whether in the Bundesliga, or a cup game or a Champions League qualifier is going to be played to right the wrong of that final. Every win, every goal is going to be about getting back there again.

And remember that left-footed shot I told you about? Think about it.

Think about it when you do reach the Champions League final that year. Think about it when, in the second half, shortly after Bayern takes the lead, Borussia Dortmund ties the game 1-1.

Think about it in the 89th minute, with hardly any time remaining.

Cut in from the right, control with your left.

And let it go.

The eight years you have at Bayern Munich will be the proudest of your career. Three Champions League semifinals. Three finals. One Champions League trophy. Six Bundesliga titles. Four cup trophies.

But aside from the trophies, the titles, I donâ€™t think I can prepare you for how much this club will come to mean to you. Maybe even more so because you didnâ€™t expect it to.

So what else can I say?

Well, for one thing, there will be a pretty strange exit from the Champions League in 2017. Iâ€™ll just leave it at that.

But what I really want you to know is that even at 33, that hunger you have now is still here. That drive to keep getting better hasnâ€™t left yet. Looking back, I think thatâ€™s what gets us here more than anything â€” that desire, no matter what youâ€™ve already done, to keep going back out, to keep getting more from the pitch.
