item.title: I Want My Damn Respect, Too
item.author: Cynthia Cooper-Dyke
item.description: I was the Michael Jordan of womenâ€™s hoops.
item.content:encoded:
(1) Do me a favor â€”Â go on and look up all the big dynasties in professional sports over these last 25 years.

Michael and Scottie and the Bulls. Brady with the Patriots. Jeterâ€™s Yankees. Shaq and Kobeâ€™s Lakers. Duncanâ€™s Spurs. Stephâ€™s Warriors. LeBron and D-Wade and the Heat. All the big ones. Look them up.

O.K. â€”Â now hereâ€™s something thatâ€™s interesting about those dynasties:

They never won four in a row.

All of those teams, as great (and I mean great) as they wereâ€¦.. they never went back to back to back to back.

Now: Three in a row? Thatâ€™s been done.Â

Five, or six, or however many, over however many years? Also been done.Â

But four in a row??

Nope.

See, four in a row â€” that would be something legendary. You figure that if a dynasty ever won four straight? Youâ€™d be watching movies about them. Theyâ€™d be airing TV specials and writing books about it and whatnot. You figure, four in a rowâ€¦.. thatâ€™s something truly special. Thatâ€™s immortality right there.

You figure.

Hereâ€™s the thing about it, though.

I won four.

We won four.

From 1997 to 2000, the Houston Comets won four consecutive WNBA championships.

And I wonder how many of yâ€™all reading this even know our story.

I wonder how many of yâ€™all out there actually know who I am.

(2) I was the Michael Jordan of womenâ€™s hoops.

Thatâ€™s real!! Trust me.

Itâ€™s real and Iâ€™ll tell you why.

The similarities between me and Michael? Man, they were crazyâ€¦â€¦.

First of all, Iâ€™m the same age as Michael. Same exact age, no kidding. Michael was born only two months before me in 1963. And from there, if you go back and look at it, itâ€™s like we were on these kind of parallel paths. Michael was the top high school player in his state. I was the top high school player in my state. Michael could have played college hoops anywhere, but he chose to stay at home in Carolina. I could have played college hoops anywhere, but I chose to stay at home in L.A.

Michael won a national title with UNC in â€™82.Â

I won a national title with USC in â€™83 (and â€™84 â€” but whoâ€™s counting).

We both established ourselves as elite scoring guard prospects.

You see what Iâ€™m saying? Itâ€™s these parallel paths.

After that, though, our paths diverged.

Because when it came time for Michael to go pro?? Well, you know the deal. Third overall in the â€™84 Draft â€” and the rest is history.Â

By â€™98 heâ€™s the GOAT.Â

My history, on the other handâ€¦â€¦. it reads a little bit different.

(3) I was one of the best young women's basketball players in America â€”Â and America had nothing for me.

No professional womenâ€™s league to play for. No draft. Had to go to Europe to make any money â€” and by any money I mean any money. I signed with an agent, hoping to get a spot in the Italian league, but not many teams in Europe were looking for guards at the time. So the only offer I got was from this small team in Valencia, Spain.

One year for $20k â€” thatâ€™s what being one of the most promising young talents in the game got me, coming out of college: a minimum salary contract overseas.

Did it sting? Yeah, it stung.

But at the same time, I accepted my one-year deal for what it was: an opportunity. A â€œshow meâ€ contract. And I set out to do just that. I got my butt over to Spain and I said, You know what â€” letâ€™s see what I can show this league. Letâ€™s just play it out and see what happens. Letâ€™s see what Iâ€™ve got.

Rookie year I think I averaged 37 points per game.

No lie, 37 per. Thatâ€™s not a misprint. I mean, Iâ€™m pretty sure I had a 67-point game somewhere in thereâ€¦.. I had a 50-point game in thereâ€¦.. I had a few nights. I was that L.A. bucket bucket. It was a good season, and it put me on the map with some of the teams in Italia.

(That means Italy, by the way. I speak fluent Italian.)

(4) I ran the Italian league for about a decade.

After my season in Valencia, I ended up signing with Parma â€” you know, where they make Parmigiano-Reggiano, Prosciutto di Parma and all of that?? â€” and that was big. That was prime time. Like I said, Italy was the premier league. All the great players were wanting to play in that league. Which meant two things: One, yeah, they had more money to throw around. But also, two, they werenâ€™t just handing out long-term contracts left and right. Everyone was fighting for those paydays, for that security. You really had to turn some heads to last in Italy for more than a minute.

And so again, Iâ€™m just like â€” man, on one hand, does it sting a little? I average 37 my first year as a pro and Iâ€™m still scrapping?! Yeah, it stings. But I took it on as just another opportunity.Â

Or maybe even more than an opportunity, I took it on as a challenge: Do I belong here with the best of the best? Or am I about to be back in L.A. running pickup? Only one way to find out.

First season in Parma, I think I almost averaged 40.

Second season, I averaged 40 and won league MVP.

All total, I ended up spending 10 seasons in Spain and Italy, and won eight scoring titles.

I was runner-up the other two.

(5) I wonâ€™t say I had mixed emotions about playing overseas â€” because I didnâ€™t.Â

I loved my time in Europe. Those were amazing years. You really have to understand â€” Iâ€™m a kid from Watts. And Iâ€™d have these moments where it was just, like.â€¦.. alright hold upâ€¦... how did I get here?? Howâ€™d I end up on this CANAL in VENICE, taking a damn BOAT from one arena to the next, for my JOB of hooping??? Howâ€™d I make it from the inner city to the Duomo??

That still blows me away. So as far as my career overseas goes, itâ€™s all love.

But love is complicated, you know what I mean??

And I think I felt some of that over the course of my run in Europe. I think there were times where maybe Iâ€™d be coming off a 50-point game or something, or Iâ€™d hit two free throws in OT with zeros on the clock for the win, or Iâ€™d dominate a big rival, and it would just kind of hit me, likeâ€¦.. damn, I have to admit, it would have been nice to do that with 20,000 people chanting my name. Or it would have been nice to be on SportsCenter for some highlights, or in the sports section of the L.A. Times the next morning with a write-up. Or it would have been nice to know that any of my people back home had really any idea at all about the levels I was reaching on this other side of the world.Â

And so I wouldnâ€™t say I felt cheated out of anything, necessarily â€” but I still definitely had these moments where I was aware of what I was missing out on, just by virtue of being a female player instead of a male player, and where Iâ€™d think to myself, you knowâ€¦.. wouldnâ€™t that be nice.

Like I said, it was complicated. It was bittersweet.

(6) In 1996, an American womenâ€™s professional league started up called the ABL.

Finally!!!! Right???

As soon as I heard about it, I reached out to them about joining â€” and I figured my chances had to be good. Iâ€™d just spent almost a decade leading the top league on the entire planet in scoring.Â

They passed, though.

Yup â€” they just straight-up passed on me. Told me thanks but no thanks. Said they already had â€œenough guards.â€Â

That one hurt, I wonâ€™t lie.

But it was also a helpful reality check: I was 33 years old by then â€” I was at the end of my prime. And I think the ABL not wanting meâ€¦.. that really forced me to get right with the idea that, as far as my playing professionally in the States was concerned? That probably was never going to happen. And as far as American hoop fans were concerned? My career was pretty much destined to go un-remembered.

It just was what it was â€” the opportunity had passed me by.

I accepted that.

And then a funny thing happened.

(7) Summer of â€™96, I started hearing some whispers.

Started hearing some loud whispers. I was still out in Italy, playing what would end up being my last season there â€” and I started hearing these rumors about â€œanother league.â€ Another American womenâ€™s league.

And then after a while, they started to become more than rumors.Â

Now it was: This league is real, Coop. This league is happening.Â

Now it was: The NBA is part of this.

O.K., wow.

So you know how I was saying before how Iâ€™d accepted that I wasnâ€™t going to play professionally in the States?? Alright well nevermind all of that. Once I heard the NBA was getting involved, it was like â€” Nah thatâ€™s it. Iâ€™m in.Â

Letâ€™s go.

I put together my stats, my film, plus a cover letter and a rÃ©sumÃ©, and I called the league office â€” my contact was this woman named Renee Brown.Â

I said, â€œHi, Renee, my name is Cynthia Cooper. Iâ€™m playing overseas right now. Playing in a city called Alcamo. Iâ€™d really love to be a member of your league. I'm going to ship you off a box with my numbers, my video, et cetera, et cetera.â€

And she's like, â€œWait. Cynthia? Cynthia Cooper who plays in Italy?â€ I said, â€œThatâ€™s me, yeah.â€

And she goes, â€œGirl we've been LOOKING for you. You're in our top eight! Where do we send the contract?â€

Now â€” on the outside, listen, Iâ€™m an adult. So Iâ€™m keeping my composure, telling her my mailing address, staying nice and calm. But on the inside? Man Iâ€™m like a little kid in there. Iâ€™m behaving like a child!! Iâ€™m screaming. Iâ€™m out of my MIND.

We finish talking logistics, and I thank her for her time. â€œNo, thank you,â€ she says.

â€œWelcome to the WNBA.â€

(8) One thing Iâ€™m proud of, about my journey, is that I never got bitter.Â

It was tempting to, at times, believe me â€” even during the best of times.Â

Honestly, in a lot of ways, it was even more tempting during the best of times.

Like take this WNBA launch in 1997. On one hand I couldnâ€™t be happier. Iâ€™d wanted something like the W to happen so bad. And then it happened!! So I should be ecstatic, right??? And mostly I was. But there was still that sting.

There was still that old sting, that Iâ€™d felt so many times before.

There was still that moment where Iâ€™m thinking, Waitâ€¦â€¦. hold up. Yâ€™all are launching a league now?! As in: NOW now??? As in, when Iâ€™ll be 34?!? You couldnâ€™t have launched this during my prime, over these last 10 years?? While I was giving them Michael numbers in Italy?? While I had a whole career to look forward to?

Thereâ€™s still that sting of living out your dreams on somebody elseâ€™s terms.

Itâ€™s a sting that I think is pretty universal for women in the world of sports, and frankly for Black women in the world, period.

But like I said: While it might have stungâ€¦.. it never made me bitter.Â

And Iâ€™m proud of that. Iâ€™m proud of how Iâ€™ve never let myself get bitter about â€” or feel entitled to â€” anything thatâ€™s come my way in this game, or in this life.Â

Iâ€™m proud of how, instead of worrying about being the oldest damn rookie that anyone had ever heard of?Â

I went ahead and was the best damn rookie that anyone had ever seen.

(9) People knew, but they didnâ€™t know, you know?

Look â€“ there were people in the W who knew I could play.

Iâ€™m not going to exaggerate here. We didnâ€™t have social media at the time, and obviously they werenâ€™t broadcasting my games on ESPN or what have you â€” but if you were paying a decent amount of attention, you probably knew who I was. Real heads knew I wasnâ€™t some scrub.

Still, though â€”Â realistically, there were two ways that most people in the States had gotten any of their womenâ€™s hoops information: One, by watching college. Or two, by watching Team USA in the â€™96 Olympics. And I wasnâ€™t on that Olympic squad... and I definitely wasnâ€™t in college. So just off that alone, I was relatively anonymous.

And then the other thing I had going against me, if weâ€™re really keeping it honest here, is my age. Folks saw that 34 number next to my age and â€” even if they knew I could play a little bit â€” they just figured: Sheryl was the franchise player. Tina was the stud rookie. And I was the veteran brought in to help our team jell. To guide some of these younger players along. To lend a steadying hand.

Whatâ€™s ironic is â€” I actually did all of those things! I was 34. I was that steady vet. I did help our group jell. I did guide those young guns along.

I also just happened to do one other thing.

And I happened to do it really, really, really well.

I got buckets.

(10) As well as I was playing that first year â€” I still felt like I was having a â€œslow start.â€

I mean, I was hooping.

O.K., I was more than hooping â€” people were picking me as midseason MVP of the whole league.

But in my mind I was still kind of holding something back.Â

I guess the way I looked at it was: Coach Chancellor still didnâ€™t know me. Tina was still trying to spread her wings coming out of USC. The offense was still really structured around Sheryl â€” and with Sherylâ€™s pregnancy and her being out for a while, I wanted to make sure everyone knew that I was team-first. So it was this very new, not exactly permanent situationâ€¦... and I didnâ€™t want it to seem like I was power hungry or anything. I made a point to try not to ruffle any feathers, and to just play within the flow.Â

I tried to get my buckets naturally as they came.

But Iâ€™ll never apologize for my talent. And the thing of it is, even naturally, even within the flow of the offense, even with me being Deferential Coop, by around midseason I was still averaging near 20.

And then what happened next Iâ€™ll never forget.

We were playing the Sparks at the Forum, and they whupped us pretty good. I think we lost by like 25 â€” our fourth loss in seven games. I had 17, but it might as well have been 7.

And for whatever reason, something just snapped in place that night. I realized two big things. 1. Like it or not, this was my team. I was our leader and our best player. And our losses were now a reflection on me in a way that I needed to learn to accept. 2. My Deferential Coop thing mightâ€™ve made sense in the beginning of the season, when we were all figuring stuff out â€” but the truth is? I had another gear in me. Man, I probably had another two or three gears in me.

And after that Sparks game, I let Coach Chancellor know it. I went right up to him in the locker room and I said, â€œCoach, straight up, I can give you more.â€Â

At first I could tell he was a little confused. He goes to me, â€œMore? What do you mean more? Theyâ€™re already saying youâ€™re MVP.â€ But I just held firm. I was like, â€œI donâ€™t care what theyâ€™re saying about me. I know I can give you more. If you let me go, Iâ€™m telling you, I can give you more.â€

And Coach just looks at me for a few seconds, still all quizzical, and finally he says, â€œWell..... alright, then. Alright, Cupper.â€ (He never pronounced my name right. Still doesnâ€™t to this day.)

The next two games I went for 30 (W) and 32 (W) â€” and then I gave Sacramento a 44-piece to close out the road trip. (Another W.)

And thatâ€™s about when it all changed for me. Thatâ€™s when my mentality went from not wanting to ruffle any feathers, to ruffling whatever feathers I deemed necessary in order to help our team win. Thatâ€™s when I went from being a 34-year-old rookie with a chip on her shoulder, to being a superstar player with a team on her back.

Honestly? Thatâ€™s when I became Cynthia Cooper again.

(11) Alright, quick story time here.

Itâ€™s 1998 and Iâ€™m on top of the world.

1997, the Wâ€™s first season, that was a Triple Crown year: MVP, finals MVP, championship.

And itâ€™s hard to even express the emotions I was feeling from all of that. Satisfaction. Elation. Vindication. Thankfulness. Swagger. Hunger for more.

But now itâ€™s the spring of â€™98, and weâ€™re at this gym in Italy, and thereâ€™s one emotion that I can feel coming on in particular: pride.

O.K., actually, hold up â€” let me give you some context first. Remember the ABL? The league that had told me they had â€œenough guards,â€ didnâ€™t need me, didnâ€™t want me, thanks but no thanks? Turns out they might have needed me after all, because they folded after two seasons. After they folded, we absorbed some of their best players into the Wâ€¦. one of those players being their first-ever MVP, Nikki McCray.

So now like I said itâ€™s the spring of â€™98, right before our second season is about to tip, and the W has a bunch of its stars over in Italy for an exhibition game â€” promote the league and so on and so forth. Nikki is one of those stars. And of course me being the reigning MVP, Iâ€™m also one of those stars.

So anyway we play the exhibition, itâ€™s a normal exhibition atmosphere, not too serious â€” weâ€™re doing our thing. Then after the game we stick around and sign some autographs.Â

Alright now hereâ€™s what happens.

Weâ€™re signing autographs, and I get handed this basketball to sign â€” and I sign it, â€œMVP.â€Â

Nikki, just seeing my signature, she says, â€œHeyâ€¦.. maybe Iâ€™ll sign it MVP, too.â€Â

And I love Nikki, by the way, let me establish up front.

But yeah, she said that. Maybe Iâ€™ll sign it MVP, too.

And I justâ€¦.. I canâ€™t even describe it to yâ€™all. I just give her this look, man. This look.Â

And then I shoot back and I say, â€œO.K. â€” you do that. Just donâ€™t put WNBA MVP on it.â€

Thatâ€™s how it was back then, I am telling you!! If youâ€™re judging me from that story, all I can say isâ€¦.. youâ€™re right. I had 10 years taken from me, in the dead center of my prime, just by virtue of the W not existing yet. And I knew that at 34 (now 35), my time left in the league was limited. But as long as I was in the league?? I was going to make that limited time count.Â

And that was just my attitude about it. Not about attention, or publicity, or endorsements or any of those things. But about greatness? About winning?

Once I found my gear â€” whew boy. I was an apex predator.

And like I said: I was proud.

(12) Letâ€™s talk about The Dynasty now.

Iâ€™ll keep it straightforward for yâ€™all.Â

Hereâ€™s what you need to know about the greatest basketball team of all time â€” the 1997â€“2000 Houston Comets.

THE RÃ‰SUMÃ‰:

Four years. Four rings.

THE MAIN CHARACTERS:

Van Chancellor

Coach was a playerâ€™s coach, if you know what I mean. Wasnâ€™t exactly about drawing up the old Xâ€™s and Oâ€™s. Wasnâ€™t about these big long practices, either. But he was a gentleman through and through â€” a brilliant manager of people.

Janeth Arcain

So famous that she only went by Janeth.

Tina Thompson

The young gunner. Tina had that unique ability to line up at the four and the five â€” to be very, very physical and play against the Lisa Leslies of the world â€” while also having the finesse to step out and knock down threes with NBA range. I know a lot of W players do that now, but please recognizeâ€¦. at the time, that was unique to Tina. Every stretch big since then is just following the Tina Thompson blueprint. And let me say one more thing about TT: thereâ€™s not another kid Iâ€™ve EVER met who, fresh out of college, could have handled what we asked of Tina during that very first run. The fact that she went on to become an all-time player, I mean, that didnâ€™t shock me at all. Tina was different from the jump.

Kim Perrot

You know something? Iâ€™ll just leave it at this: She was my best friend.

Sheryl SwoopesÂ

She had her own shoe!! Itâ€™s hard to explain how big of a deal that was. Manâ€¦. itâ€™s hard to explain how big of a deal Sheryl was. And thatâ€™s not even the first thing that comes to mind when I think of her. First thing that comes to mind is â€” well, I call it a miracle: the way that Sheryl came back after having a baby, let me repeat, after having a baby, to help us win that first championship. I think itâ€™s cute how other athletes still go on thinking theyâ€™ve done something special, after Sheryl did that.

THE EXPERT ANALYSIS:

Hereâ€™s how I look at it.

There are other W teams that have been truly great â€”Â there are other W teams that have won two, three, even four championships.Â

But none of them won a chip while we were around.

No one else won a damn thing while the Comets were on.

(13) And now this is the part that it really pains me to write about.

This is where we have to discuss the fact that the Houston Comets donâ€™t exist anymore.

I remember it was such a normal day when I found out. You know those days?? Where itâ€™s so normal you almost canâ€™t even remember what you were doing? It was like that. I was at home, Iâ€™m pretty sure. And then all of a sudden my phone started blowing up. Had people calling me, texting me, Coop, you alright?! â€” people hitting me up every which way. Friends, teammates, mediaâ€¦... everyone.Â

And the first person I actually spoke to, I think it was one of our local reporters here in Houston, a guy named Mark Berman. I called him back. And he was like, â€œCoop, what do you think about the Comets folding?â€

I said, â€œWhat â€” Iâ€™m sorry, what??â€Â

I was in a state of shock.

And itâ€™s not like he had to explain it to me, either. I knew all about the realities of this business. I knew all about the history of womenâ€™s sports franchises folding. I know money makes the world go round.

But that didnâ€™t mean it shocked me any less.

And I guess I also always believed in my heart that there were some things more important than money. I guess I always felt like, O.K., with all due respect, there are different levels of franchises. There are different types of situations. Like if you need to move the San Antonio team to Vegas, because thatâ€™s financially viable?? I donâ€™t love it, and I feel for those fans in San Antonioâ€¦.. but maybe I can understand it. Maybe I can learn to see a move like that as a cost of doing business.

But youâ€™re going to FOLD â€” fold â€” the HOUSTON COMETS??!?!?!??Â

Youâ€™re going to fold the franchise that won your leagueâ€™s first four championships?????

Like, to me, when you do something like that, itâ€™s beyond dollars and cents. A franchise like the Comets, thatâ€™s history â€” and not just my own history, or the WNBAâ€™s history, or anything like that. The Cometsâ€¦.. thatâ€™s sports history. Itâ€™s womenâ€™s history. Itâ€™s Black history.

And I think itâ€™s dangerous to treat our history like that.

A franchise like the Comets, thatâ€™s history â€¦.. thatâ€™s sports history. Itâ€™s womenâ€™s history. Itâ€™s Black history.

After I got off the phone with Berman, I spoke with Tina and Sheryl â€” and it was just surreal. It was like weâ€™d lost this part of us. It was likeâ€¦.. I mean, you have to understand something.Â

You have to understand how it all comes back to pride.Â

You have to understand how proud we were of what we accomplished together, winning the Wâ€™s first four chips. Proud for ourselves? I mean, yeah, sure, on some level â€” we were proud of what weâ€™d built for ourselves, and for our team. But it was so much more than that.

We were proud of what weâ€™d built for the Comets as a franchise.Â

We were proud of what weâ€™d built for Houston as a city.Â

We were proud of how, as far as history was concerned, the Comets were now the WNBA Celtics. Or they were the WNBA Lakers. Or they were the WNBA Bulls, or Spurs, or â€” you pick.Â

The Comets were a living, breathing part of what happened.

1997.Â

1998.Â

1999.Â

2000.

For four years we stitched ourselves into the fabric of this league.

And in one press release they ripped us right out.

(14) Before I finish, letâ€™s talk about these GOAT conversations for a second.

Because I think theyâ€™re pretty interesting.

To me, whatâ€™s been going on over this last year with Michael, Kobe and LeBron, itâ€™s beautiful. Just with how we had The Last Dance earlier in the year, and everyone reminiscing about all of Michaelâ€™s accomplishments, and how he capped it off with that final ring. And then we had 8/24 Day in the summer, and I was so moved by everyone sharing all their stories about Kobe, sharing their memories of what made him such an assassin, such a model of toughness, such an amazing champion. And then of course you had everything that transpired in the bubble, toward the end of the year, with LeBron winning his FOURTH ring â€” on his third team! â€” and being named Finals MVP.Â

Thatâ€™s been so beautiful to me.Â

Those three momentsâ€¦.... I feel like theyâ€™ve combined to create something very special. And I feel like theyâ€™ve almost been this reminder, in some type of way, of the kinds of conversations we actually should be having, when weâ€™re talking about things like â€œthe GOATâ€ â€”Â when weâ€™re talking about players at the level of LeBron, or Kobe, or Michael, or Magic Johnson or Bill Russell or whoever else.

I feel like itâ€™s been this reminder of how â€” itâ€™s not about there being one GOAT to rule them all, you know what Iâ€™m saying? Itâ€™s not about there being one GOAT and we have to choose.Â

Ainâ€™t never been about that.

Itâ€™s more about there being a whole lineage of GOATs.Â

Thatâ€™s how I look at it.

So, for me? Itâ€™s like â€” man, of course LeBron is the GOAT. Look at that manâ€™s career!! Look at all that heâ€™s been able to accomplish.

I felt the same way about Michael in his time, and Kobe in his time.

Itâ€™s a lineage.

And just like the mantle is now being passed on to LeBron, eventually LeBron will pass the mantle on to some player who comes after him. And by then, as a matter of fact â€” weâ€™ll probably be watching some documentary about LeBronâ€™s â€œlast dance.â€

That makes me so happy. I love that about this game.

But if Iâ€™m being honest?

I also wish we were seeing some more of that on the womenâ€™s side.

Because I take nothing away from Diana. I take nothing away from her ever. Everything LBJ has done for his generation in menâ€™s basketball, DT has done for hers in womenâ€™s.

Iâ€™m the first in line to call Diana Taurasi the GOAT.

But itâ€™s still a little disappointing to me, I guess, how with Diana â€” everyone just started doing it almost out of thin air. You know what Iâ€™m saying??

I hope that makes sense.

Again: Dianaâ€™s earned it. She is that great. She is that GOAT. But itâ€™s just never felt like anyone has cared enough to trace a lineage to Diana as GOAT â€” to show any context for it, or to have any fun with it, or to nurture any healthy debate about it. Itâ€™s almost felt like, for most people in the media and whatnot, womenâ€™s basketball has only recently started to exist.

I havenâ€™t seen a Diana vs. Sheryl conversation, or Diana vs. Lisa, or Diana vs. Tamika.

Or yeah, Iâ€™ll say it: Diana vs. Cynthia.

I havenâ€™t seen much understanding of what it means to call Diana the GOAT.

And I know itâ€™s not that serious â€” I know itâ€™s not that deep.Â

I know itâ€™s just talk.

But I also think itâ€™s too bad. Because in a lot of ways, that talk, those conversationsâ€¦.. theyâ€™re really what make a title like GOAT mean something in the first place.Â

Womenâ€™s basketball deserves to have those conversations.

Womenâ€™s basketball deserves a history.

(15) I still wonder a lot about what my place is in this game.

Am I one of the greatsâ€¦.. or was I just a table-setter for greatness to come?

Did my career matterâ€¦.. or am I fading away?

I think I could have fit five of my hands inside his palm. He was a big deal in Orlando, too, of course. There were pictures of him all over the store, and his jersey was everywhere.

NBA basketball made me proud to have been born there.

Because I had been born in the States, and my dad was from there, I felt like I was a part of American basketball. Like I was closer to it than all the kids I played with back in France. Even as a seven- or eight-year-old boy, I was always proud to introduce myself in class as Killian Hayes, from Lakeland, Florida.

But one thing I want to make clear is this: France is absolutely a basketball country, too.

Dad had played college ball in the States, and I knew his journey hadnâ€™t been straightforward. He never made it to the league and he had to grind really hard in Europe to make a name for himself. He knows the game of basketball â€” and the world of basketball â€” more than most people.

I think he knew that if I wanted to do this, like if I really wanted to try to be a basketball player, then I had to love it. I had to love coming to the gym each day. I had to love the process. And when I got to be 11 or 12 years old, he saw that in me. I was a determined boy. When Iâ€™d come back to America in the summers, and weâ€™d go down to the rec center and Iâ€™d play against some really good players who were older than me, thatâ€™s when I knew I could play this game.

My dream wasnâ€™t just to play basketball forever.

All those YouTube videos and trips to the CityWalk had left a mark on me.

My dream was to play in the NBA.

But the road from Cholet to the NBA draft was hard to navigate.

When I was 14, my dad was considering coming back to Florida to try to play professionally. So we also talked about me going to one of the big high schools in the States to get myself ready for college ball.

And I wanted that, real bad. I had seen so many videos online of the McDonaldâ€™s All American games and the big AAU tournaments and all those different youth basketball events. Most kids that age are juniors in high school, but there I was going up against grown men â€” playing for their livelihoods, in games that truly mattered to the clubs. The teams in France rely on the prize money for making the playoffs and the gate proceeds to stick around, so each game really matters. It made me see the game a bit differently.

My dad knew that, and I also think he knew that I would rise to the challenge.

I had to mature quickly. No time to complain about playing time, or who gets the ball when. We were in the business of winning games. That was what mattered.Â

My older teammates helped me out, on and off the court. I couldnâ€™t get my drivers license in France until I was 18, so my first few years with Cholet my parents and teammates used to have to drive me to and from practices and games. People always offered to help because they knew I cared so much about Cholet. I had been going to the arena since before I can remember. I knew the club really well. Itâ€™s one big family.

You just gotta go do it.

All of those experiences have prepared me for whatâ€™s next.

Iâ€™m ready to cross an objective off my list.

Iâ€™m ready to be a professional basketball player in the NBA.

Everything Iâ€™ve done in my life has been leading to this moment.

For those who donâ€™t know the heptathlon, itâ€™s seven events: hurdles, high jump, shot put, 200m sprint, long jump, javelin, and 800m run. Itâ€™s beyond legit. And like I said, my mom was insane. (9) LETâ€™S GO, INDY.

As you got older, you started to discover that the sport exists outside of your backyard. You and Dad would watch channel nine on Saturday nights to see those great Toronto and Montreal teams play. Sittler, Salming for the Leafs. Lafleur, Robinson for the Habs. These guys lit up on the TV. And since Dad was from Boston, on family vacations up there during the holidays, youâ€™d go to the Garden with him and see the Bruins play. The electricity in the building stayed with you long after you left.

Back home, it was just a 30-minute drive to the Joe in Detroit, where the Wings played. They were going through a tough stretch back when you were a boy. But the fans in town always had a great passion for their team. Hockey, in that part of our country, meant a lot to everyone. And the Wings gave back to their community in a bunch of different ways. You were part of that when you started going to Little Caesars hockey camps when you were 10. That took the game to a whole new level for you.

Through those camps, you were able to see more games at the Joe and fall in love with the sport even more. You began to compete against some of the best players in the area, and that led to a tough decision.

One thing a lot of people donâ€™t know is that you thought about trying to make it in tennis. You were a pretty good player as a boy, and for a bit you considered going to Florida to try and really give it a run in tennis.

Mike Modano, the tennis pro. Maybe in another life.

But in this life, you chased that feeling of freedom that only hockey could give you. That led to you, Mom and Dad making another big choice. Going to Canada for juniors was the best option if you were going to try and make it to the NHL. But it was a big choice. Mom was a bit hesitant to send you up there, especially because you were only 16.

Rick Wilson, the head coach of the Prince Albert Raiders in Saskatchewan called you up in the summer of â€™86, telling you how he wanted you to come up there and what he believed was possible for you. There was no changing your mind after that.

But in this life, you chased that feeling of freedom that only hockey could give you.

Do you remember how confident you were in the decision?

Mom and Dad â€” though they wanted a few more years of you at home â€” knew it was the right call, too.

In Prince Albert, youâ€™d meet two of the most important people youâ€™d ever come across.

Ralph and Carol Ring, your billet family.

One of their sons, Martin, had just moved out, but Stephen was still there. They made your transition from Livonia to your new home as easy as you could have ever imagined. Ralph worked as an executive with the Raiders and Carol worked in city hall, but she would sing the anthem before games. They, like everyone in the town, had a deep connection to the team. The Raiders were the heartbeat of Prince Albert.

Coach Wilson and his wife, who was also named Carol, were such great leaders for that team.

You know, itâ€™s funny, because when people think of you down the road, a lot of them are going to remember you for your skating. That will be a point of pride for you. But what they wonâ€™t know is that you were a bit of late bloomer when it came to really finding that explosive stride. It wasnâ€™t until Carol Wilson, who was a great figure skater, worked with you that you started to find that next level. She made your stride a bit longer and all of sudden you gained a step on some of the older kids playing in the WHL.

Thatâ€™s what people in Prince Albert do, they help one another.

It was a small farm town, but they loved their hockey. I mean, of course, the whole country of Canada did. The word passionate doesnâ€™t quite cover it. So when you got to town, there was definitely some push-back about an American being up there and scoring as many points as you did. I know you remember that part. Some of the other teams always had a few guys in their bottom six that wanted to take a run at you or remind you that you werenâ€™t at home anymore.

But you got through it. I know how much you loved Prince Albert once you got to know it. You spent summers up there and youâ€™ll keep in touch with those friends you made outside the rink for life.

In the summer of â€™87, you began to see what could happen when your time with the Raiders was done.

That year, the draft was at the Joe in Detroit. Even though you werenâ€™t eligible until the next year, you and Dad went to see what it was all about. A few of the guys you played against in the WHL got picked in the first round, including Joe Sakic. You lined up against him a couple of times the year before. He was a great player and you knew if you worked hard in your draft year, you could have a chance to go early in the first round, too.

That next season, you didnâ€™t hear much about the draft until after the world juniors ended in Moscow in January. You guys didnâ€™t have a great tournament, but when you got back home the NHL released the Central Scouting Bureau draft rankings, and you saw your name up at the top with Trevor Linden.

Hereâ€™s the thing about the draft, that you might not fully appreciate for some time: Going first overall will mean a lot to you â€” to American hockey â€” as you get older. I know, at the time, you just wanted to be an NHL player. But receiving the honor of being the second American to be selected first â€¦ thatâ€™s a big deal. Trevor was a great junior player, so to battle with him through the end of that â€™88 season will help you grow.

The draft was at the forum in Montreal. Your whole family was there with you, including Ralph and Carol.

I know you knew that it was likely youâ€™d go first or second, to Minnesota or Vancouver. But I also know you looked up and down that draft board and let your mind wander. You saw Pittsburgh had the fourth pick and you wondered, A career playing beside Mario â€¦ what would that be like?

But when Lou Nanne made the call to take you first overall, youâ€™d learn that Minnesota was the place you wanted to be. That passion Michiganders have for hockey is matched by Minnesotans. And you were lucky to join a franchise like the North Stars.

The TSN interview after the pick, where you were sweaty and more nervous than youâ€™d ever been, wasnâ€™t your best. But at least your braces were off. Did you forget how you got them off a few weeks before? New teeth, new job. Pretty good week, I think.

After another year in Prince Albert, you finally had to say goodbye to the Rings and the Raiders. You headed to Kalamazoo for training camp with the North Stars in the summer of â€™89 and you learned, real quick, that the NHL was a big step up from the WHL. You walked into the locker room and saw guys like Brian Bellows, Stew Gavins and Basil McRae. You werenâ€™t in Saskatchewan anymore.

You also realized in your first practice that you werenâ€™t the fastest anymore.

That shook you a bit. But everyone in the room did a good job of welcoming you and making you feel a part of the team. That made your rookie season a bit easier.

But, Mike, Iâ€™ve got a quick piece of advice for you here.

Donâ€™t get in another fight. Just donâ€™t do it. I know, I know, when you dropped the gloves with Rod Brindâ€™Amour that year, it made sense in the moment. But, yeah, he handled you pretty good. You did your best â€¦ but just donâ€™t look up the fight on the Internet when youâ€™re older either. That part of the game just isnâ€™t for you, pal.

In Minnesota, you grew into the player you always wanted to be. The Stanley Cup run in â€™91 taught you a lot about what it takes to win in this league. You guys snuck into the playoffs that year with 68 points, but you learned quickly that it doesnâ€™t matter how you got there â€” what matters is that youâ€™re there.

The fans in Minnesota packed the arena every night during those playoffs and you only lost one home game before the Cup final. That Pittsburgh team that you ran into, man, they were good, right? Mario, Jagr, Coffeyâ€¦. They could really play. They beat you guys in six, and it stung for a while.

I know you remember that feeling this year before you played Buffalo.Â

But, of course, thereâ€™s a big difference with this yearâ€™s team. You arenâ€™t playing for Minnesota anymore. The team moved to Dallas in 1993 and I know it wasnâ€™t easy on you to say goodbye to the people of Minnesota. You were one of the leaders on that team and those last few games at the Met Center were pretty emotional. I know seeing those little boys and girls in their North Stars gear â€” knowing they wonâ€™t have a team the next year â€” that hurt.

But hockey is a business sometimes, you know that.

Not many of the guys could really believe that theyâ€™d be heading to Texas, though.

Remember when they broke the news to the team.

Dallas? Really? Thatâ€™s Cowboy country.

They had won back-to-back Super Bowls the year you headed out there and it was pretty obvious that, no matter what you did, or what they did, they were going to be the front-page story. In a way it took some of the pressure off of you as players. You were able to do your thing and try to help build up a fan base however the team wanted because people were pretty new to the sport. America wasnâ€™t the hockey hotbed it is now. In â€™93 it had only been a couple years since the Gretzky trade so the southern half of the country was still coming around on the game.

But, you noticed right away how nearly every fan who made it to a game in those first few years left with a smile on their face. And they always wanted to come back for another one. Even though the team struggled a bit those first few years, you were all building something special down there.

Those Dallas fans are smart when it comes to their sports though, you saw that. After a couple of years of being there they wanted a winner. In â€™96, when things werenâ€™t going so well, Ken Hitchcock came in to coach the team and things began to change, almost immediately. He pushed you hard. There were times when guys in the room would look at each other like, Can this guy just relax for a day?

But that was Hitch.

That summer after he came in, you sat with him and Bob Gainey, the GM, and you worked out how you could help this team get over the hill and bring a Cup to Dallas. You all decided that it would be best to add some more dimensions to your game, to make you a 200-foot player and those types of responsibilities would be given to all the veterans on the team.

You know, when you look back on how the â€™99 Cup run came to be, youâ€™ll remember the preseason trips to Vail. When Hitch took over, he made those trips to Colorado mandatory before the season started and it really helped all the guys get to know each other. There was a lot of bonding, training and a bit of golf, too. That trip in â€™99, everyone knew before the season started that the team had to make a deep run that year. The fans in Dallas were hungry and they knew you and the team were capable of getting it done.

You saw how the team shaped up that year. You knew going into the playoffs that this was going to be special. From the veterans in the room like Brett Hull and Guy Carbonneau, to leaders like Derian Hatcher and Joe Nieuwendyk and all the way through the lineup to Ed Belfour in net â€” this group was built to win big games. You just had to prove it.

When you look back on how the â€™99 Cup run came to be, youâ€™ll remember the preseason trips to Vail.

In the Conference Finals you played that great Avalanche team with the guy you saw in â€™87 at the draft, Joe Sakic. They were an excellent group and after they beat you at home in Game 5, you were down 3â€“2. Those next two games, and you know this, they were some of the best hockey youâ€™ve ever been a part of. From top to bottom Hitch had you guys executing in every zone, on every shift. To go back to Colorado and win there, then to survive a Game 7â€¦. Iâ€™m sure it felt like destiny that you would beat Buffalo in the finals.

But now youâ€™re here. In the locker room of the Marine Midland Arena in Buffalo, and itâ€™s getting late.

Itâ€™s Game 6. Youâ€™re up 3â€“2 in the series. And youâ€™re about to head out there for triple overtime.

Look around. You see how beat the guys are?

Look at Hitch. He even looks tired.

But, man, this is it.

When you get out there, just try to get the puck in their zone. Thatâ€™s the first step. Theyâ€™ve got an incredible goalie in Hasek. Heâ€™s on tonight. Youâ€™ve got to get some traffic in front of him and make him work. As the period goes on, just try to cycle it and make them skate as much as possible.

Late in the frame, when the body is hurting the most, thatâ€™s when youâ€™ll get your chance.

Youâ€™ll get the puck in the corner, youâ€™ll shake free of Zhitnik and try to play along the wall. The puck will sort of fumble toward the net, so stay with it. Hully will be out there with you and itâ€™ll be one of his first shifts in a while because of his knee. Heâ€™ll be near the crease and then itâ€™s just going to happen.

Itâ€™ll be a blur. No matter how much detail I describe it to you in, itâ€™s going to be a blur.

Youâ€™ll be trying to get the puck and next thing you know, Hasek will be on his stomach and Hully will be screaming.

Itâ€™s not going to take two days or two weeks for it to hit you that you won the Stanley Cup â€” itâ€™s going to hit you right then and there. Itâ€™s the best feeling in the world, Mike. It really is. Youâ€™re going to cry for two hours straight that night, I promise.

The pain in your wrist, in your legs â€” itâ€™ll all just fade away in a split second as you wheel into the corner with Hully.

Youâ€™ll skate around the ice with the Cup over your head, and itâ€™ll feel like it weighs a pound, not 35.

When you get back to the locker room, before the press and the friends and family can come in, there will be a moment.

Everyone on the team, from the coaches to the players, will have a chance to huddle in the middle of the room and tell each other what this experience â€” what this night â€” means to them. I want you to look around at all those guys and really soak it all. Remember your own journey. From the lake in Livonia, to Saskatchewan, to Minnesota and all the way to Dallas. Think about all the people who made this possible. Know each guy in that room has a story like yours.

Appreciate those guys and what youâ€™ve all just accomplished.

Youâ€™re going to cry for two hours straight that night, I promise.

When you get back home to Dallas, and you see Young Street packed with thousands and thousands of Stars fans, itâ€™s going to blow your mind. There will be hundreds at DFW to welcome you back when you land, too. Itâ€™s going to be incredible, trust me.

But what will take some time to set in is that your team changed the sport of hockey in the state of Texas â€” forever. Youâ€™ll notice in the few years after the Cup that the atmosphere at your home games is truly the best in the league. The fans will stand all game during the playoffs and every shot, hit and goal will sound like a touchdown at Cowboy Stadium. Dallas will become a hockey destination, because of what that â€™99 team did.

That to me, Mike, is legacy.

Be proud of that.

The Stanley Cup isnâ€™t everything. But I wanted you to really appreciate the journey you went on with those guys, and know that that team still matters to the people of Texas.

Thereâ€™s plenty more for you in the game after â€™99.

But, to be honest here, I donâ€™t want to spoil it all for you.

Thereâ€™s great things coming. From playing for the Wings, to retirement, to seeing your jersey go to the rafters in Prince Albert, to the Hockey Hall of Fame â€” this game will give you more than you could have imagined.Â You'll meet Allison, the love of your life. She will be your best friend and with her you'll find the most fulfilling life after hockey.Â But most importantly, youâ€™ll become a father to Kate, Jack, Reese, Luca and Quinn.Â Your family will be the greatest blessing of all. And thatâ€™ll change the way you see the world forever. I canâ€™t wait for you to experience that.

There will come a time in your life when youâ€™re not playing hockey anymore. Youâ€™ll go to events, or meet people, and somebody will introduce you as â€œMike Modano, one of the greatest American hockey players of all time.â€

I know you didnâ€™t grow up thinking about becoming that. All you wanted was to be a good teammate and win a Stanley Cup. But I hope that when that day comes, and you see the impact you had on the game, that it means something to you. Your generation of American players â€” guys like Hully, Tkachuk, Guerin, Roenick and so many others â€” helped pave the way for the game to reach another level here in the U.S. Those world-class players youâ€™ll see on TV when you get older, know that some of them look up to you guys right now.

You and your family worked hard to reach this point, know that. Youâ€™re one of the lucky ones who gets to play this game for a living.

So when you head out there for triple overtime, remember to cherish every second of it.

And make sure Hully gets the puck.

I studied Kawhi on defense. I watched a bunch of Jrue Holiday. And OF COURSE I watched LeBron. Thatâ€™s a given.Â Â

I probably looked crazy to the people in the cars that would drive down my block, eyes closed, acting like Iâ€™m somebody else, shooting fadeaways.Â

My dream was that when I got out of Gwinnett, Georgia, people would be saying, â€œMan, back in the day? That Devin Vassell kid was crazy!â€

My dream was that people would pack out my high school games. Standing room only. And I thought Iâ€™d be one and done, going almost straight to the league. Buuut, if Iâ€™m telling the truth, it wasnâ€™t really like that. Like at all.

They were booing me.

Record scratch, freeze-frame. â€œYouâ€™re probably wondering how I got here.â€

I donâ€™t mean they were booing the team or our fans or something like that.Â

They were booing ME, specifically.

It was definitely a movie moment. Just not the one I had imagined.

It was more like the movies where the hero is in some crazy situation, and itâ€™s like, Record scratch, freeze-frame. â€œYouâ€™re probably wondering how I got here.â€

Let me rewind a bit.

My dad had played college ball back in the day, and my brother was so much older that he was already playing basketball by the time I was born, so it wasnâ€™t long before one of them put a ball in my hands.Â

I just fell in love with the game, instantly. Really as soon as I can remember.

Me and my dad spent a lot of time in the gym together when I was growing up. But we started out just going to parks with my ball. I used to go to Collins Hill Park over by the high school over there, and Peachtree Ridge Park, which was part of my high school. Thereâ€™s a lot more parks in Gwinnett, too. Bogan Park. Listen, I could go on and on about some parks.

After tryouts, the first roster gets released. I made that cut, so Iâ€™m like, Oh, yeah. I know Iâ€™m straight.

I went to talk to the coach thinking, Thereâ€™s no way my nameâ€™s not on there. But sure enough, theyâ€™re like, â€œYeah, sorry. We just donâ€™t think that you have the ability to make the team this year.â€

And the kicker: â€œBut you can be a manager.â€

Iâ€™d love to say that I took it really well. But Iâ€™d have to have been some extremely mature seventh grader.

I said, â€œNah, Iâ€™m straight,â€ and walked out of that gym so quick. I had a rolling chair in my room, and there was probably about three seconds between me storming through the front door of my house and me putting that chair through the wall. I left a huge hole. Then I went stomping around the neighborhood.Â

I was like, Nah, there is no way. There is no way I didnâ€™t make this team.

Honestly, it brought down my confidence a lot.

And if it wasnâ€™t bad enough that I didnâ€™t make the team, the assistant coach was also my social studies teacher. So I had to see this man every day after that!!! Heâ€™s asking the class about British parliament or whatever and Iâ€™m just steaming.

I finished out the school year, and that summer, I transferred schools. I went to our rival school.

When I was a sophomore at Peachtree Ridge High, and my first varsity game came against those kids at my old school whoâ€™d made the team ahead of me just a few years before, I was a skinny kid with a point to prove.

But as soon as I walk in the gym, Iâ€™m already sick to my stomach. Iâ€™m thinking, Iâ€™m finally here. Iâ€™m in front of all these people that knew me at my old middle schools.

And when I came out of the tunnel, everybody started booing.

Like, â€œBoo, Devin!â€Â

Oh.

That was my reaction. â€œOh.â€

Coach says, â€œAlright, Devin, itâ€™s time for you to go in,â€ and my heart starts pounding.

I get in the game, and Iâ€™m playing my role. Whole time, the crowd straight trashing me. Just talking a whole bunch of mess.

We come down the court, and I spot up in the corner. They pass the ball to me.

The clank of a brick means you at least got close. You hit the rim. But I didnâ€™t even do that. I airballed in front of all those people who knew me from before and were waiting for me to fail.

I said, â€œOh, no. Oh, no.â€

When I came out of the tunnel, everybody started booing.

I think everybody whoâ€™s ever tried to be really great at something has a story like that. They had a game where they just ... werenâ€™t good. I know I probably have a few more of those moments to look forward to in my NBA career.

But those moments are learning opportunities. I know that no matter what exactly is ahead of me, there are going to be ups and there are going to be downs, both on and off the court.

Iâ€™ve already dealt with some of that. Some of the biggest challenges Iâ€™ve faced, people donâ€™t even know about.

When I was around sixth and seventh grade, my family was going through some things. I donâ€™t like to talk too much about whatâ€™s going on in my private life. I keep everything in-house, especially when it comes to family stuff.

But one of the greatest challenges Iâ€™ve faced in my life was back then, when my mom had been having severe back issues and had to go through surgeries and stuff like that. She had been a nurse up to that point and used to work long hours, but she couldnâ€™t work anymore and had to go on disability.Â

Just seeing her sometimes not feeling her best was very tough on me mentally as a kid. Maybe more than I even realized.

Seeing that it wasnâ€™t as easy for her to do some stuff anymore, like getting out of the car, or just walking around â€” when that kind of thing happens to someone thatâ€™s very important in your life, it can take a toll.

Iâ€™m lucky to be close with both of my parents, and theyâ€™ve really tried to prepare me for everything thatâ€™s ahead of me. Weâ€™ve had a lot of talks, but mainly their message has been to stay grounded. They told me, â€œBe who you are, stay humble, and remember where you came from.â€

Iâ€™ll never forget those lessons.

And I wonâ€™t forget that no matter whether I won or lost, or when I didnâ€™t make the team, they never stopped believing in my dream.

Thereâ€™s still so much more that I have left to prove. Iâ€™ll always have that mindset. Thatâ€™s not going to go away, no matter the success, no matter whatâ€™s going on in my life.Â

I think that just growing up my whole life and not being ranked, not getting some of the credit or recognition I feel like I deserved, it definitely stays with me.

But it also makes this moment â€” right now, as I prepare for draft night â€” that much more of a blessing.Â

Itâ€™s a blessing to be where Iâ€™m at, and Iâ€™ll never take that for granted.

Alright, one last story. March 2019, ACC tournament quarterfinals. FSU vs. Virginia Tech.

Weâ€™re down three, with about seven seconds left in the game.

I was on a hot streak and had made three of five three-pointers.Â

Everybody had been telling me, â€œYouâ€™re hot, youâ€™re hot. Keep shooting if you get open.â€Â

So now, weâ€™re in the huddle. A play is called. Iâ€™m in the game, but the play isnâ€™t just for me â€” there are options. Trent Forrest was inbounding, and there was somebody wide open, right next to him.Â

But when we came out the huddle, I said, â€œBro, listen, if you pass it to me, Iâ€™m shooting it.â€Â

He looked at me. I said, â€œIf you pass it to me, Iâ€™m shooting it. So take it for what you want.â€

And he was just like, â€œAlright.â€

So, Trent gets up to the line, and he looks. He sees me come up the screen and just darts it to me.

I come off of a flare screen to the corner and hit the three, with a hand in the face.Â

I looked back at Trent and said, â€œWell, I told you.â€

We ended up winning in overtime. And the craziest thing about it all wasnâ€™t even the hot streak I went on that night. It was that they came to the freshman.

They came to a freshman for that. Itâ€™s just the fact that they had that much confidence in me. Not only the coaches, but my teammates.Â

It was huge. It meant everything.

When I was younger, my goal was always to be one and done, always. Elementary school, I was like Yeah, Iâ€™m going to be at the McDonald's game. One and done. Itâ€™s wraps.Â

item.content:encoded:
During every pregame skate, I used to look into the crowd and wonder what the fans could see.

I mean, like, what could they really see?

Could they see the cuts on my hands â€” and the blood on my laces â€” from obsessively lacing and relacing my skates again and again?

Could they see the bags under my eyes from having gotten just two hours of sleep for the fifth straight night?

Could they see the pain I was going through from trying to work up the nerve to tell the coach that tonight was the night when it was just all too much, and I couldnâ€™t play?

Iâ€™ve been an NHL player for 11 years. And until very recently, Iâ€™ve had untreated obsessive-compulsive disorder, or OCD as we commonly know it.

There is simply no way to overstate the impact itâ€™s had on my career, and on my life. It controlled me, it almost broke me for good. And there were times when I thought I might never be able to tell a story like this. But Iâ€™m here, and I am.

I want to tell this story because, really, itâ€™s not about me. Itâ€™s about what happened to me, yes â€” but itâ€™s not about me. Itâ€™s about, hopefully, getting people help. Even just one person. I know, without a doubt, that there are athletes and people all around the world suffering from the same thing I do, or something similar. Because I understand what OCD, if left untreated for too long, can do to a person.

The thing is, in the beginning, it seemed harmless. And I remember the beginning.

I mean the very, very beginning.

When I was little, maybe seven or eight years old, Iâ€™d count the trees when I would go on car rides with my parents. Iâ€™d be in the back seat of our caravan, and Iâ€™d watch them go by.

One, two, three, four.

Then Iâ€™d restart.

One, two, three, four.

The faster we went, the faster the trees would pass and the faster Iâ€™d count.

It didnâ€™t seem out of the ordinary. It was just â€¦ I donâ€™t know, the way I was.

My OCD manifested itself in different forms throughout my life. When I was in junior hockey, and even when I played at BU. I worried constantly about injuries. Iâ€™d think about my knees when I was on the ice, despite never having had any knee problems before. I had a chronic groin injury from when I was younger, and when it would be flaring up, Iâ€™d just drop down into a squat while I was doing everyday things to make sure it was O.K.

It was that feeling of a lack of control that eventually triggered the negative thoughts â€” like the ones I used to have during pregame skates.

And itâ€™s almost this entirely separate part of your brain that gets activated when this happens. For me, my ability to play hockey never felt threatened when I was young. I grew up in Winnipeg, and like so many kids, I wanted to play in the NHL. And I always knew deep down that I was going to make it. My dad and grandfather had both played in the NHL. Itâ€™s all I ever wanted to do. Itâ€™s all I ever wanted to be.

My OCD played a role in making me the player I was.

For a long time, I didnâ€™t have negative thoughts on the ice. I obsessed over my game, but in a positive way. I wanted to be the best player I could be because it was â€¦ it was everything to me.

My OCD played a role in making me the player I was. And I know there are many athletes out there who have that same connection. They might be afraid to seek help because on the outside theyâ€™re â€œsucceedingâ€ and they wonâ€™t want to change anything. I know I can tell them that that isnâ€™t the case, but I also know they might not believe me.

Because I probably wouldnâ€™t have believed it, either.


When the Nashville Predators took me in the first round of the draft in 2008, it was such an incredible moment to experience with my family. I had no negative thoughts or concerns about any of my OCD tendencies. I was just me. Colin Wilson, NHL player. Thatâ€™s what mattered. And at the time I donâ€™t think the term OCD had ever been brought up to me or had even crossed my mind.

Iâ€™d always tried to hide anything I did that could have been classified by others as superstitious or odd. But once I reached the NHL, I basically couldnâ€™t anymore.

I remember in 2010, my rookie year, when Predators GM David Poile sat me down with assistant GM Paul Fenton, team psychologist Gary Solomon, and my parents and told me I had OCD.

They had noticed after picking up on a preflight routine Iâ€™d go through at airports.

To be honest, Iâ€™m a bit hesitant to talk about this part, because my tendencies, my experiences, theyâ€™re personal to me. And I donâ€™t want anyone to read this and feel bad for me, or to think Iâ€™m glorifying what I went through. But I feel itâ€™s important because the element of control â€” of having it or not having it â€” is what pushes people with OCD into dark places.

Before a flight, I had things I needed to do. I had to clean up all the trash around our gate. Every single wrapper, piece of plastic, you name it. Into the trash. Then I had to be the last passenger on the plane, no matter what. Then, finally, I actually had to talk to the pilots. It didnâ€™t have to be about anything specific, but I had to at least talk to them. After I did all that, I felt safe to fly.

It stemmed from a fear of flying Iâ€™d had ever since I was a kid â€” and had grown into this routine. It all revolved around control of the situation. I needed to feel like I had a hand in what was going on.

But at the time I completely discounted what David Poile and everyone else was telling me. I was a 20-year-old living his dream in the NHL. I felt fine, I felt healthy.

Thereâ€™s no chance I have that, I thought.

I donâ€™t know what would have happened if I had taken that talk more seriously. Which is one of the reasons I want to help those who are facing the same things I did, because I know what itâ€™s like being on the other side of the table. It can be hard to accept what youâ€™re hearing. And I didnâ€™t. I just ignored it and told them I would be fine. I hid myself, and my issues, from everyone.

After that, I basically spent the majority of my career in what Iâ€™d call fight-or-flight mode.

To this day, I honestly have no damn clue how I scored 20 goals in the 2014â€“15 season. I played each game, for years, in this state of panic because my OCD had begun to take over every element of my life. I went from obsessing over injuries off the ice to thinking I was going to get hurt every time I stepped on it â€” thinking I'd get hurt every shift. Or feeling like my skates werenâ€™t tied properly. Iâ€™d have to stay in the locker room and tie them over and over again, as tight as I could, until my hands bled. And that was just a short-term fix. For years, I felt like I was skating on stilts because my skates never felt right. But I just got into this terrible state, like a petrified animal trapped in a corner. I was almost unconscious on the ice, in a way.

I was so energized after games that I couldnâ€™t sleep, and the lack of sleep led me down a road that I wouldnâ€™t wish on my worst enemy. I truly mean that.

Thereâ€™s a version of this story where I tell you what happened next.

I read those kinds of stories all the time, and I think theyâ€™re very powerful and important. The bravery and honesty of those who have gone through the darkest of moments and can share their experiences with others should be applauded. But what I went through is just for me to know right now, and I hope youâ€™ll respect that.

All I can say really is that, during the Stanley Cup finals in 2017, when we were playing the Penguins â€” I hit bottom.

My brain blew up.

I was a shell of the person I am today.

For the three or so years leading up to that point, I had been taking Xanax and Seroquel to help me sleep. One is addictive and gets you high, the other I would refer to as a horse tranquilizer, because it would knock me out. One night I would take Xanax, the next Seroquel. During that playoff run, I had started partying more as well, to numb the pain. The combination of those pills, mixed with alcohol, and years of untreated OCD â€¦ I found rock bottom.

Those had been prescribed to me to help me. But they didnâ€™t do that at all. They made me lose myself. The stressors I had â€” the OCD, the lack of sleep, the pressure of playoff hockey â€” those pills just seemed to amplify all that and drive me to a place I never wanted to get to.Â

The combination of those pills, mixed with alcohol, and years of untreated OCD â€¦ I found rock bottom.

It became so bad that I remember when we beat Anaheim to win the Western Conference finals, everyone on the team was, of course, really happy. But all I wanted to do was go home and bawl my eyes out. I was a complete emotional wreck. I felt like I hadnâ€™t been playing my best. I felt like I hadnâ€™t contributed enough to the success of the team and it was driving me insane.

One of the things about OCD is that you have this internal critic that nags at you â€” that constantly reminds you that, no matter how hard you try, you arenâ€™t ever in control, and because youâ€™re not, you arenâ€™t good enough.

And in the Cup finals, I was barely able to function. I was running on fumes, my head felt like it was on fire â€” I felt like I was going insane.

I knew I couldnâ€™t live like this anymore. The team and my family had noticed that I wasnâ€™t myself. When the season ended, after we lost the Cup finals, I realized that the only choice I had was to truly heal myself. I had started talking to a therapist earlier that season when I was really struggling, but what happened in the playoffs pushed me to work on myself even more.

After Nashville traded me to the Avalanche that summer, I continued to keep my issues from nearly everyone. But one of the most important connections Iâ€™ve ever made in my life was when I was introduced to a trained plant-medicine facilitator after the trade.

The way in which so many mental health cases are treated with pills and other addictive, unhealthy measures, really didnâ€™t sit well with me. So under the guide of my facilitator, I started taking doses of psychedelics and other similar medicines that may seem unapproachable for many. But it was that sort of alternative help that did so much for me.Â

The word psychedelics might put people off, I get that â€” but I canâ€™t stress enough how critical they were in my recovery. That experience showed me a completely different side of myself and gave me a deep sense of spirituality. It put me in touch with a part of me that I didnâ€™t even know existed. I felt like what I was experiencing was greater than myself, my journey, if that makes sense.

Finding this differing approach changed my life, without a doubt.

Alternative medicines are important and should always be considered when treating mental health issues.

I have a plan for how to help introduce it to others, but it wasnâ€™t just finding myself spiritually that helped, of course.

In 2019, during my second year in Colorado, I made another really significant breakthrough â€” I contacted the NHLPA, which put me in touch with an OCD specialist. And meeting that person changed my life. It was like meeting with a psychic, in a way.

He asked me if Iâ€™d ever felt like I was going crazy, if Iâ€™d ever felt like my world was completely out of control. My jaw was on the floor. I couldnâ€™t believe what I was hearing. He was asking me â€” almost telling me â€” about myself and connecting with me like someone who actually got it. He wasnâ€™t just there to prescribe some numbing drug or tell me to just think about something else.

For the first time in my entire adult life, I felt understood.

In those sessions, I began to understand that one of the key steps in the healing process is not only acknowledging that whatâ€™s going on in your brain isnâ€™t normal, but also, more importantly, acknowledging that it isnâ€™t your fault.

Since I started with the specialist, Iâ€™ve learned to develop a sense of self-compassion that I didnâ€™t have before. Itâ€™s so difficult to not blame myself when I feel my mind going to â€¦ that place. So now I do my best to be aware, to tell myself that things like that will happen from time to time, and to just assure myself that itâ€™s going to be O.K.Â


I knew my OCD wouldnâ€™t go away just because somebody could see it for what it was. And I wonâ€™t lie to you ... every day since then has been hard. I still have an internal alarm that goes off when I feel like I need to be in control. It can be exhausting to deal with. But every day since that meeting last year, it has also gotten easier.Â

But this last year has been tough. I had to have double hip surgery in December 2019 because of issues that came from the groin problems Iâ€™ve had since I was a kid. But my hips havenâ€™t healed properly, and I havenâ€™t been able to walk normally all year, so I just had to have it done again. Itâ€™s hard because I havenâ€™t been on the ice in a long, long time. I havenâ€™t had much control.

I donâ€™t know when I will again, either.

If Iâ€™m being honest, I think my days of playing hockey are probably over.

I havenâ€™t quite come to terms with it fully. But that is the truth.

Iâ€™ve done a lot to prepare for my next step in life. Iâ€™m completely sober. Iâ€™m back at school in Boston working on a psychology major. The last few years Iâ€™ve been working with a new, more traditional talk therapist who has been one of the pillars that I lean on as I transition toward life after hockey. Theyâ€™ve helped me think through everything and see the next chapter of my life in a positive light.

Iâ€™m also working with a group of people I got connected with over the last three years of getting help, and weâ€™re going to open a space in Austin for alternative medicines and approaches to mental health issues â€” OCD included.

Mental health, and what we know about it, is evolving and so must the ways we treat it.

We want to help people, both physiologically and neurologically, through things like neurofeedback, floating, assisted psychotherapy, and other alternative therapies that arenâ€™t widely accessible. Weâ€™ll also have teaching programs to ensure that once you leave, youâ€™ll know how to keep up your routines on your own. Itâ€™s going to be a space that completely strips any stigma away from mental health issues. It will be a place that will be nourishing and safe, for all those who desperately need it.

Mental health, and what we know about it, is evolving and so must the ways we treat it.

I want people to know that there are spaces where you can be yourself, where you can feel understood and loved and know that there is help there for you. I want that to be what you take out of this story.

The human experience includes an incredible amount of suffering, even if youâ€™re living your dream. There are lots of people battling OCD right now. I know how brave they are, how strong they are for fighting it. I know itâ€™s probably taken over their lives, and they feel like thereâ€™s nowhere to turn to, or nobody to help them â€¦ to understand them. But I want them to know that there is someone. And I hope that they know Iâ€™m here to help.

We canâ€™t get through it alone.

If it werenâ€™t for the people who truly helped me â€” my spiritual counsel, my alternative medicine facilitator, my OCD therapist and my talk therapist â€” I wouldnâ€™t be the person I am today. Thatâ€™s my team, and they have given me the opportunity to help others.

Thatâ€™s my focus in life right now.

And like I said, I donâ€™t know if Iâ€™ll be back out on the ice anytime soon. But I know that, no matter what the future holds for me, I did it. I played in the NHL. I lived my dream. And I fought through hell to make a career for myself. My name might not be on the Stanley Cup, and thatâ€™s fine. Because I know there is an opportunity ahead of me to not just leave my mark on the game of hockey, but also on lives all across the world.

I donâ€™t want to pretend like I have it all figured out, because I donâ€™t. Iâ€™m still learning as I go. But what I do know comes from what I went through. So if youâ€™re going through it, remember this:

Be kind to yourself, to your mind.

Have patience with your soul, your body.

And know that you donâ€™t have to do it alone.

â€”Colin
